text:
7/27/06  My girlfriend made this, then called me up saying it did not turn out like mine, after going through the recipe, I asked her what BBQ sauce she used.  She bought Kraft on sale for .77 cents.  Using good BBQ sauce is just as important as using good wine.  Use Jack Daniels or Famous Daves etc.  Stay away from the cheap sauces as they do affect the flavor of the foods. If you don't like sweet, don't use a sweet sauce. 
We really loved this recipe.  If making this during the week, I season chicken with garlic powder, a little salt and pepper add a can of 99% chicken broth and throw in crockpot and cook on low for about 6 to eight hours.  When I get home I drain grease shred chicken and pour rest of ingredients over chicken for about an hour to blend flavors.  I use Famous Daves bold sassy barbeque sauce.  When making on the weekend I cook on high for about four hours, drain, shred chicken and pour rest of ing. over chicken and cook for about two hours more to blend flavors.  I also like to add a little onion and green pepper in the morning then put back into crockpot after draining.   We put it on hoagie rolls or steak rolls  that I brush with olive oil and broil till lightly brown.  Served with a green side salad and fresh cut up veggies and dip.  Yummy Yummy Yummy.  Thanks for the post.

text:
I too used fresh chicken breasts and cooked them on high for 3 hours.  I then shredded the chicken and cooked on low for 1 more hour. (Note: I only used 3 chicken breasts)  I followed the recipe exactly and thought it turned out perfectly.  For those who commented that the sauce was watery - shredding the chicken will help absorb it and make sure you are using a molasses based sauce and not a vinegar based sauce.  I live in Kansas City so we definitely know our BBQ and this turned out great!  Before serving the chicken, I brushed an olive oil and garlic salt mixture on the outside and inside of the bun and broiled for a few minutes until toasty.  I also found a Chipotle Cheddar Cheese by Sargento that was a nice addition.  Finished off with red onion slices.  Will definitely make this again.  Very good reheated too.  UPDATE: With the left over chicken from last night, I made a salad with black beans, corn, onions, and chipotle cheddar cheese.  I added the left over chicken and finished by drizzling a 2 part BBQ sauce, 1 part Ranch dressing mixture over the salad.  Very yummy!

text:
I love this sauce!  The only change I made was to add about 1/2 cup of diced onion and 1 teaspoon of liquid smoke.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's Honey barbecue sauce and the sauce was perfect.  The chicken is wonderful but the recipe also lends itself well to boneless pork ribs.  I threw them in the crockpot and poured the sauce over them.  In about 8 hours I had the most tender, juicy ribs ever!  Used the extra sauce to pour over the ribs once they had been served.  A very big hit!

text:
I added about 4 cloves of minced garlic & half a diced onion... my breasts weren't frozen so I only cooked on low for about 4 hours. Then I removed the chicken & shredded it, adding it back to the sauce, along w/ a tbp. or two of Wondra. (It's a non-clumping flour used in sauces & gravies. It's sometimes called "instant flour"). This thickened the sauce up nicely. I stuffed baked potates w/ this & added cheddar cheese & chopped onions. These were better than our local BBQ joint's stuffed potatoes! I served them w/ fresh corn on the cob (nuked) w/ parmesan butter.

text:
Outstanding recipe!  Added 3 cloves of minced garlic, one tbs of liquid smoke and Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory and Brown Sugar BBQ sauce!  To avoid the wateriness of this dish that other reviewers have noted, try using chicken that has not been frozen and adjust your cook time accordingly.  Served on rolls with carmelized onions and choice of cheese with a side of sweet potato fries....  My family of men LOVED this dish!!!  HELPFUL HINT:  Use the leftover chicken on Texas Chicken Quesadillas found on this site.  Outstanding way to use up the leftovers!

text:
YUMMERS! I used Jack Daniels original BBQ sauce, added an onion, sliced, only used 3 large chicken breasts, and per the other reviewers, added some flour about an hour or more before the end of cooking. I didnt want my chicken to dry out so I was doing the 6 hour recipe and had to crank the heat to high for the last 2 hours or my chicken would not have been done. 
I shredded the chicken about an hour before it was done and served it on fresh cibiatta rolls, with pickles and red onions to top them. SERIOUSLY easy and good. Served with sweet potato fries. Everyone licked their plates clean.

text:
Oh my Gosh!!!! Can I give this 10 stars? I was looking for an easy recipe one day that didn't require a lot of effort on my part and came across this recipe. I had almost everything needed for it as well, which usually isn't the case with most recipes I find. I LOVE the fact the chicken can be thrown in frozen. I threw 6 frozen breasts in the crockpot, used Sweet Baby Ray's Vidalia Onion BBQ Sauce, the amount of brown suger the recipe calls for, Heinz Worcetershire Sauce, and.....ooops! No Italian dressing! No problem! I substituted Kraft Light Balsamic Vinagrette dressing. I worried how the taste would be affected but it was INCREDIBLE! Next time (and there WILL definitely be a next time,)I may throw in some red onion bits as well.

The sauce came out perfect in consistency as I broke the chicken up when it started getting tender and allowed it to remain in the crockpot to thicken up and absorb the BBQ sauce.

Do yourself a favor and try this!!! You won't be disappointed!

text:
...And here's to adding to the MULTITUDE of positive reviews this recipe so rightly deserves!  Followed the recipe pretty much to the 't' with the exception of lessening the brown sugar (to about a heaping 1/8 c) to cut back on sweetness and added 4 lg garlic cloves squeezed through garlic press.  Also, (and this is very important to me and others might find this just as important) I did NOT use frozen UNCLEANED chicken breasts.  I could not believe the endless reviews I read where people just plopped their frozen 'uncleaned' chicken breasts into the crock pot without thinking of all the YUCK that will also be included in your dish since it was not trimmed off!  Even if you partially defrost (quickest way is by placing breasts in lg bowl and completely covering with cold water then dumping and replacing the water every 10 - 15 mins) you can then 'clean' your chicken! --a must for us!  With using 6 sm - med size defrosted 'trimmed' chicken breasts, I had no problems with the consistency of the sauce.  It was perfect! Cooked on high for 2 1/2 hrs, and as one reviewer suggested, removed to shred and returned to pot and continued cooking for an addt'l 45 mins to meld.  I used Kraft Zesty Italian and 12.5 oz of 'Sweet Baby Ray's' original bbq sauce.  Served on toasted 'Francisco International' French sandwich rolls! (with bread & butter pickles on side).  Unbelievably delicious!  Seriously, will never need to go 'out' for a bbq fix again.  For sure 'restaurant quality' at home!

Fantastic!!!  My wife is not really even fond of BBQ.  Well she said this recipe was a keeper!  I took heavily in consideration the two “Most Helpful” reviews.  First I used Sweet Baby Ray’s Original BBQ sauce.  I can see that a subpar sauce would really mangle this recipe.

As per the suggestion, I used fresh chicken breasts, used the same other ingredients as per the recipe and added 1 cup of diced onions.  Cooked for three hours on high, shredded the chicken and then put on low for one hour. Wow!  This will definitely be on rotation.  Oh and my picky three year old loooooooved it!

Enjoy and thanks for the recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
I'm giving this recipe 5 stars for it's basic idea and simplicity. But I changed it up, made it even simpler, and even more yummy (if I dare say so!) Forget the other ingredients, all you need is the frozen chicken, a large bottle (or 2 med. bottles) of your favorite bbq sauce, some brown sugar, and a dash of your favorite all-purpose seasoning.   I used 4 large frozen skinless breasts, added somewhere between 14-16+ oz of Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ Sauce (the best!), 1/4 cup of light brown sugar, and 1 TSP of Spice World's Cajun Blackening Seasoning, but any all-purpose seasoning would do. No pre-cooking stirring necessary, just dump it all in on top of the chicken. Cook on low 3-5 hrs, then while chicken's still in crockpot, gently shred/pull apart using 2 forks. Let simmer on low for another hour (or several, depending on your timeframe) and remove crock from heat and stir. Sauce will thicken as it cools/stops boiling. BEST pulled bbq sandwiches our family's ever eaten! This is my husband's new favorite meal. Tip 1: If near eating time your sauce seems super watery, remove lid for half an hour. Tip 2: The quality of your bbq sauce directly translates to the quality / flavor of your chicken, so choose it wisely! Tip 3: Freezes great in Ziploc bags!

text:
I read the reviews & knew I didn't want shredded chicken, so I decided to bake it it the oven instead. I prepared the chicken in a 13x9 & covered it with foil & put it in the fridge for a few hours. Then baked at 375 covered for 30 minutes & uncovered for 15. (spooned sauce over after removing foil.) Everyone loved it & the chicken was tender. (it was fresh chicken, not frozen) Thanks for submitting!

I used fresh chicken (not frozen) and only BBQ sauce (KC Masterpiece) and Lite Italian Dressing. I cooked the chicken for 4 hours and let it sit 'warm' for a few hours. When I got home from work I shredded the chicken in the pot and then let it sit a bit longer, though it really only needed about 10 mins. It was AWESOME!!!!   I baked sweet potatoes and put the chicken on top. Add some veggies and you've got a great easy meal. Even my picky toddler loved it and now we have food for tomorrow!

Easy and tasty. I used unfrozen chicken breasts and only used 3 large.  Like other reviewers suggested, I used half bottle of (12 oz) BBQ sauce for the mix then cooked on HIGH for 3 hours - shredded chicken and then added the rest of the BBQ sauce and cooked on LOW for 1 more hour. text:
Made this recipe exactly as written; although I did cut the recipe in half, since it’s the two of us. I only use Sweet Baby Ray’s BBQ sauce so of course it was delicious!  I highly suggest using this BBQ sauce, no others come close; and I am picky with my sauces.  I can’t believe how easy this tasty meal was to prepare and cook, the flavor payoff was awesome.  I used three thawed chicken breast, cooked it on low and after 3 hours I shredded it and then returned it to the crockpot to cook for another 1.5 hours.    The sauce was perfect, not runny at all! Not too savory and not too sweet…perfect!  I piled the chicken on top of lightly toasted King’s Hawaiian rolls, and paired with corn on the cob. Fantastic recipe, zero flaws.

text:
This was extremely easy and very good.  I loved the idea of using frozen chicken.  No need to thaw it first just throw it all in the crock pot!  Be sure to freeze your chicken breasts separately!  I mixed up the sauce the night before and in the morning just put it all together.  I doubled the sauce ingredients and used 10 chicken breasts.  It cooked on low for about 11 hours.  It did seem a little dry when it was still whole, but by the time I shredded the breasts and put them back into the sauce, it melted in your mouth.    I served it open faced on bulkie rolls with a slice of provolone and a slice of cheddar cheese on the roll first.  This would be a great recipe for a summer BBQ!  Be sure to use a good sauce as stated before.  I used Jack Daniels and it was just delicious.  Thanks for a real keeper!

text:
Quite good...very simple.  Contrary to what appears to be popular opinion here, a "non-gourmet" BBQ sauce tastes just as good in this recipe as a more expensive brand.  I do not use the brown sugar called for in this recipe since my wife felt it was too sweet when prepared that way previously but I do add about 2 heaping teaspoons of minced garlic to enhance the flavor.  After cooking I pour about 1/2 of the sauce back over the pulled chicken, mix together and serve this to those in the family who want a milder BBQ flavor.  For the rest of us I take the remaining sauce and add cayenne pepper, black pepper, and apple cider vinegar to taste and drizzle this over each sandwich.  This moves the sandwich eastward in the direction of a NC BBQ flavor.  A shot of Texas Pete or your favorite pepper sauce does no harm on these fine sandwiches.  Nor does a batch of slaw or tater salad as a side.  You will find no need to go out to eat BBQ chicken sandwiches if you prepare this recipe.  This recipe alone makes the purchase of a slow cooker well worth the investment.  It is a low effort, sure thing for picnics, socials or bowl games.  After about 2 hours the smell of the BBQ in your home will become almost irresistible.

text:
Great taste and super easy!  I used a 3lb bag of frozen "chicken tenders" (no, not the breaded ones!), and Sweet Baby Ray's barbeque sauce (that's just an FYI, not a suggestion). I added three teaspoons of chopped garlic, a large white onion minced and about a tablespoon and 1/2 of dried mustard. I made these additions because I thought it was too sweet when I sampled the sauce. (Another brand might be more on the tangy side, but I worked with what I had on hand.)

After the chicken was falling-apart done, I removed it from the pot and did a simple reduction of the sauce (just boil it down to the consistency you want). I broke the meat into chunks instead of shredding it and served it on hard rolls.

To the people who commented that the sauce was "runny" or "thin"... I feel the blame is more on the part of the water injected into the chicken and not the recipe.... if you read the info on the package, almost all chicken is "water added"..... unless you are freinds with a chicken farmer and can get it fresh and "unprocessed", we just have to deal with that and adjust.

text:
I used 4 fresh chicken breasts (not frozen), Newman's Italian dressing, and Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ sauce.  The BBQ sauce came in an 18 ounce bottle and I think I put about 15 ounces in and saved the rest for serving on the side.  I followed the rest of the recipe ingredients exactly.  I cooked on high for 3 hours (maybe 3 hours and 20 minutes because I was late getting back home from errands).  Then I took the chicken out and shredded it with two forks.  It was super tender and already falling apart, so that was easy to do.  Then I put the shredded chicken back in and cooked on low another hour.  It absorbed almost all of the sauce after being shredded and it tasted amazing!  We had it on thicker gourmet hamburger buns with coleslaw and sweet potato fries.  The next day we made BBQ chicken pizza.  Delicious!  I'm making it again this weekend.  Might try the hickory and brown sugar sauce this time since our guests like sweeter BBQ.

text:
Best pulled chicken I have ever had. I made a couple of modifications. I used 2 lbs of fresh chicken breast (not frozen), sweet baby ray's hickory and brown sugar sauce, and Ken's light italian dressing. I cooked everything on high for 3 hours, shredded the chicken, then cooked for another hour on low. I definitely recommend using those dressings/sauces. The other recipe reviews recommended that you stay away from Kraft BBQ sauce. The sauce will make or break this recipe. It's super important to shred the chicken and continue cooking. The chicken soaks up all the sauce that way. It was a bit "saucy", but that was great over rice. Leftover are even better.

M;y family and I love this recipe SO much that I make it all the time. First time I made it I had reservations about putting Italian dressing in and thought it actually smelled funny about 3 or 4 hours into the cooking process.  However, it turned out fantastic.  I make it exactly as the recipe calls for, using KC Masterpiece Hickory Brown Sugar bbq sauce and fat-free italian dressing.  I bake jumbo baked potatoes, top them with butter, shredded cheddar cheese and this chicken shredded and some extra sauce drizzled on top.  Can I say it again??  FANTASTIC! Think I will make it again tonight........

city:

None
country:
None
text:
You can make this in 2 hours or less! The night before, I thawed frozen chicken tenders in the microwave, rinsed & dried them, and put them in the croc pot with all of the other ingredients and put in the fridge. This took no time at all. The next afternoon when I got home, I put the croc pot on high and cooked for about 75 minutes. I took 2 forks and shredded the chicken right in the pot, and let it simmer on low an additional 30 minutes. It was perfect! I saw another reviewer's advice to get GOOD quality BBQ sauce, but I used what I had on hand and it was a bit thin. Next time I'll use better sauce and it will be perfect. Oh, and I added some crushed red pepper because we like spicy. Thanks for this easy, tasty recipe!

This has become one of my go-to dinner recipes! So easy to just put the chicken in the crock pot, shred, and put on some buns. LOVE the flavor. I've gotten a lot of compliments on it whenever I've made it. I use fresh chicken breasts and cook on low for 7-8 hours. I usually shred the chicken an hour before I take it out. I have cooked it on high for 4-5 hours when I'm in a hurry and it's just as juicy/flavorful.

Very good!  I followed a few of the other reviews and I used Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce and fresh chicken breasts.  I cooked the chicken in chicken broth on high for 2 1/2 hours.  Shredded it, drained the pot and added the rest of the ingredients, minus the brown sugar, plus some diced onions and green peppers.  Simmered for another 1 1/2 hours on low.  Toasted the buns and served.

text:
This is the kind of recipe that would seem easy enough, however it's recipes like this that are not specific and can create a disaster. If you use just any barbecue sauce, it will come out terrible! I followed the recipe exactly and it was awful! It tasted like the sauce probably was not made for such long cooking. I couldnt get anyone to eat it. So sad, and glad it wasn't something I had slaved over. Also, adding brown sugar maybe also played a part in the disaster. It would have been helpful if it explained what brand of BBQ sauce to use. Either way, I won't be using this one again.

text:
This was very tasty. I made the recipe as is, except with 4 breasts instead of 6, and it came out with the perfect amount of sauce. So, if you're going to make it with all 6 breasts and like this dish a little moister, I'd suggest adding in some more of the wet ingredients. I seasoned the chicken with s&p before pouring the sauce over, and also added in 3 cloves of garlic (minced), but I'm sure the dish would taste just great without those adjustments!

text:
My 6 chicken breasts were huge (something like 2 1/2 pounds in all) so I did one and a half times the recipe.  My chicken was thawed and only took 3 1/2 hours to cook on low, wow.  Like others, I shredded the chicken at that point, turned the heat to high, and removed the lid so some of the liquid could cook off for 1 hour.  This was a good call because it would have been very watery otherwise.  We really, really liked the resulting sandwiches which is good because it made a lot!

text:
What an awesome recipe!!! I bought about 2lbs of fresh boneless skinless chicken breast (did not use frozen)~ put in my crock-pot seasoned with garlic salt and onion powder~poured the mixture over the chicken(I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce)~on high for about 3 1/2 hours then took the lid off shredded the chicken stirred really good to incorporate the sauce~ put the lid on for about another 1/2 hour. My husband ate his over a baked potatoe sprinkled with cheese and chives (AWESOME) I ate mine on a pretzel roll (AWESOME) Later that night I made BBQ chicken nachos (FREAKIN AWESOME) I will make this all the time!!! I gave the recipe to my mom and she is going to make it tomorrow with some boneless pork-chops she has in the freezer~ so we will see how it turns out. Thanks for a great recipe :)

text:
So easy and so good!!  As suggested by other reviewers - I cooked the chicken in the slow cooker in chicken broth for 4 hours (I used fresh chicken).  I then drained the broth, shredded the chicken, combined the other ingredients and added to the chicken,  and cooked another 45 minutes - 1 hr.  This was very flavorful.  The next day I used the left chicken to make a barbeque pizza - shredded chicken, red onions, cilantro, and mozzarella.  My husband really liked it on a sandwich - but LOVED it on the pizza. (One tip - I am not crazy about the dough they have in the grocery store and I almost never make it from scratch.  I go to my local pizza parlor and buy uncooked pizza dough - stretch it out into the pan and your done!  It is so much better and enough dough for a large pizza only costs me $ 2.50.)

text:
This is always a big hit at parties!  I have made this several times and have followed the recipe exactly.  I now reduce the brown sugar by half because I use Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce and its already sweet.  I also now use a mix of breast & boneless thighs.  The last time I made this was for a BBQ so I prepared it in the crock pot the day before, shredded the meat (be careful not to over-shred or your meat will look like mush), then put it in a foil pan overnight with a little extra sauce on top.  At the BBQ we just heated the pan on the grill for a little while and it was ready to eat.  I put mini-rolls out next to the pan of meat so everyone could have a mini-sandwich and save room for all the other BBQ food at the party.

country:
None
text:
Works great in a pressure cooker too!

Used all of the ingredients as written to make sure that it was a fair rating in terms of taste (Dave's Sassy barbecue, Kraft zesty Italian, light brown sugar and L & P worchestershire).

Although it was a little too sweet for me which I knew it would be, I really believe in using as written to be accurate - this would be just the right amount of sweetness for about 90% of my friends and family.

The reason that I used the pressure cooker was that I wanted to use frozen chicken and don't really trust using frozen in the slow cooker - also wanted to experiment to see if this could be cooked as a quick meal if something unexpected comes up. 

I pressure cooked from frozen for 20 minutes in chicken broth, shredded the chicken after draining, added the mixture as listed and cooked on high pressure for an additional 15 minutes - worked great for the "harried and in a hurry cook"!

Hope this is a help to someone who didn't have time to put it in the slow cooker.

text:
I've made this a few times and totally love it!  My husband and I live in an apartment and cannot have a grill..so this is about as close as we can get to BBQ :)   This recipe is easy, has a few inexpensive ingredients, and cooks on its own!  How great it that?! I follow the recipe exactly and have been very pleased with the turnout.  I'm often surprised at how many people change recipes completely and then rate a recipe.. I think that misleads others as to how good/bad the recipe is.  This is one of those recipes that's simple and tasty enough to make the way its stated...okay sorry, that was a bit of a rant ;)   I usually use Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and make a bottle of Good Seasons Italian dressing for the dressing in the recipe.. I think the GS italian gives it more of a spicier taste than store bought bottled dressing. I do not, however, put the chicken in frozen.. I completely thaw it and than put it in the crock pot.  I've used chicken breast tenderloins and chicken breasts.. I'm curious to see how chicken thighs would be with this. Friends of mine even used this recipe as a dish at their daughter's christening party as it hold in the crock pot nicely. I served mine on ciabatta rolls. Will make again and again!  Try it, you'll love it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly and the chicken came out perfectly.  The chicken tasted like I spent the entire day slaving over it, but in reality I only spent about 20 minutes total prepping it and shredding it a few hours later. I cooked this on Low for 4 hours before removing it to shred it. After returning the shredded chicken to the slow cooker I chose to turn the temperature setting to High for an hour and a half because lifting the lid on a slow cooker drastically drops the temperature and it takes quite a long time to bring it back up. I set the temperature back down to Low for the remaining two and a half hours. The chicken was extremely moist and full of flavor. The only change I will make to it in the future will be to thicken the sauce a bit... otherwise, this was perfect!

text:
I have made this recipe exactly as written a few times at the suggestion of my mom who tried it first, and we all love it! The first two times I just served it on buns right out of the crock pot, but a week ago I strained the shredded chicken so it wouldn't make the bread so soggy, and made sandwiches on buttered and grilled sourdough. I covered them with cheese, popped them under the broiler for a few to melt it, then topped them with onions, pickles, anything you want, and used the extra sauce and some ranch for dipping. My husband was impressed and full, and it was easy and delicious. I will agree with others that the bbq sauce you use will greatly affect the flavor of the chicken, I have used a couple of different sauces and I am going to try a new one next time. :)

Cheaba77

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3199662.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is quick and easy to put together and is really moist and flavorful. My husband absolutely loves it and it's now on the menu weekly (the leftovers are equally as good the next day too)! I usually halve the ingredients, which serves 3, omit the sugar, cook on low (and have used both frozen and fresh chicken, both come out great) and shred the chicken at about 4.5-5 hours. The edges do start to burn a little if you leave it on for 7-8 hours (which can make this recipe a challenge if you're trying to cook it while away at work all day!). I was a little short on Italian dressing last time and the end result was still delicious. I do recommend using a decent BBQ sauce because it does make a difference. I recently cooked on high for 4 hours, and it was still a winner. Anyone hesitating to make the recipe due to comments about thickening - I found that if I didn't open the lid to check on it more than once to give it a little stir, I didn't need to thicken it; shredding it quickly with a steak knife and fork at around 5 hours (low) did the trick to absorb any extra sauce.

text:
This recipe is so simple and so delicious. I used Famous Dave's Zesty & Sweet (I think that's the name) for the BBQ sauce. I've also made this with pork instead of chicken, and it was even better than the chicken. I used a pork tenderloin so that I wouldn't have to try to skim off a lot of fat. Maybe two-thirds of the way through, I removed the tenderloin from the crock pot and used two forks to shred the meat, then I returned the meat to the slow cooker and let it soak up the sauce. My husband said this is one of his favorites of all the dishes I've made.

text:
This is one of the best BBQ sandwich recipes I've tried.  I didn't change anything about it and loved the flavor! I used Hickory Smoke Kraft BBQ sauce and liked it a lot! I guess if I was going to change anything, I would add a little liquid smoke, but if you use a smokey BBQ sauce, you don't need it.  
The sauce was a little thin for my liking (probably cause I stuck in the chicken completely frozen).  To fix that, I put the crockpot on high with the lid off for about 2 hours and it reduced down great!

This had a wonderful taste.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and Kraft calorie-wise Italian dressing.

However, I also used bone-in chicken as it's all I had in my freezer (I did thaw before cooking, as well).  I can't stress how important it is to use boneless!!  Otherwise you'll be picking out shards of bone and accidentally swallow a few--this REALLY takes away from the taste.

This is such an easy and fantastic recipe that most people will find delicious! It is certainly true that the better the bbq sauce, the better the end result. I followed this recipe exactly with only a few minor changes to suit my taste. I used Sweet Baby Ray's bbq sauce, the thick Worcestershire sauce, and Neumann's Own Italian dressing. text:
I made this today and thought that it was very good.  I used 3 frozen chicken breast halves, 1/2 of a 12 oz. bottle of barbeque sauce, 1/2 cup of Italian salad dressing, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, 2 Tbsp of Worcestershire sauce.  I cooked it in the crockpot on high for 5 hours, removed the chicken and cut it up in bite size pieces and returned it to the crockpot for 1 more hour.  I served it on buttered/toasted whole wheat hamburger buns.  Delicious- Even my first grader cleaned her plate!

text:
**UPDATE**I had about 2+ cups leftover so I froze it. Later I defrosted and topped a pizza crust with a little extra BBQ sauce, the chicken, and some cheddar jack cheese. It was AMAZING! ***Just made this using 3 large fresh chicken breasts, Jack Danieles BBQ, and lite wishbone italian. I cut them in half for more even cooking and easier shredding. 3 hours later, on low, the chicken was ready to shred but the sauce looked thin. I removed the chicken from the sauce and shredded it. Placed it back into the sauce and cooked on high for another 30 mins without the top on. It thickened the sauce a bit and allowed the chicken to absorb a bit more sauce.  

OVERALL, it was VERY easy and taste great. Would be even better on a pizza.

country:
None
text:
I thought this was a fabulous recipe! I had two reservations initally: The first was the frozen chicken suggestion. In my experience, when using frozen breasts they normally turn out very tough. This wasn't the case w/this recipe-I cooked on high for approx 3 hours, then shredded the breasts and kept the slow cooker on the "warm" setting to allow the breasts time to soak up the sauce. The chicken was super tender using this method. The 2nd reservation was the italian dressing-it didn't seem to "go" w/the other ingredients. Because of this, i lowered the amt to 1/3 of a cup instead of 1/2. It was great! the tang of the dressing really complimented the bbq sauce. I will be using this recipe often-thanks for sharing it!

text:
This was really good.  I used Jack Daniel's BBQ sauce.  I took other's suggestion and added a med. onion and garlic.  Saute onion and garlic.  It was a little sweet.  Next time I will cut the sugar in half and add a little red pepper.  I also cooked for 3 hours on high.  Shredded, the chicken and put it back in the crock pot for another hour or so.  Might try cooking it on low if it is a work day.  I usually don't like chicken in the crockpot, but this was very good.  Update:  I made it again and cut the sugar.  I used about 3 tbs.  Much better.  I also added 6 slices of cooked bacon (cooked them first, then sauted the garlic and onion in some of the bacon fat) and added about 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes.  Everyone loved it.  Another update:  I tried it today with pork loin (that is what was on sale, I will try pork butt next time).  I followed the recipe exactly this time, but added a little garlic and onion powder to the meat before putting it in the crockpot.  It was really good.  Served it with hush puppies, coleslaw, and cinnamon apples.  Yum!

text:
I prepared this last night and it was awesome. My family ranted and raved about this meal. I stuck with the original recipe but defrosted my chicken before I put them in the crockpot(because I forgot to start it at noon). I cooked them for 3 hours on high and the meat was soooo moist. Not dry at all.I then took the meat out and shredded it and then returned it to the crockpot with the BBQ sauce. I had some dinner rolls from costco that we used for the sandwiches. For those who where having problems with the meat being dry, you may want to check doneness about an hour before. Cooking time really depends on how thick your meat is. As my son said last night "this dinner is a do over". Other words we will be having this again. ENJOY!!!

text:
Edit 08/07/2017 - The kid I was pregnant with when I came up with this recipe is 13 now. I'm so happy it's a tried-and-true for so many. I am now a HUGE fan of the Instant Pot, and if you'd like to make this in there, here's the info: 
1) 1 cup water or broth in the bottom of the pot
2) Dump your frozen chicken breasts on top
3) I used Poultry setting for 15 minutes, 10 min NPR because I forgot about it.
4) Mix sauce in a bowl while cooking.
5) Pour off the broth (save for later cooking - I used mine for IP mac and cheese the next day), shred chicken, pour sauce over, and set IP to saute for about 10 min to heat through.

Worked GREAT!

-Suzanne

Glad to see so many people like this! I use the sauce combo frequently now. A note to people who said it was runny - that may have to do with the italian dressing you're using. I always use a thicker dressing. Some of the oily dressings might cause the sauce to thin out. My favorite is Kraft Light done Right! Italian dressing.

text:
This is a good, simple, family-friendly shredded bbq chicken recipe!  Made it last night and will definitely make it again.  My husband loved it!  I was leery to use frozen breasts in the crockpot (although many people seems to do fine with it...)so I defrosted and cleaned/trimmed the breasts first.  (I used 6 smaller boneless breasts).  I used the ingredients as listed and cooked on high for 3 hrs, and removed and shredded, and then return to cook on high for another hour.  The consistency of the sauce was perfect!  If I hadn't shredded the chicken I think it would have been watery as the chicken would have had trouble absorbing the liquid.  The addition of brown sugar makes it sweet, so if you use a sweeter bbq sauce, you may want to cut back.  I served on crusty rolls with a salad.  There were no leftovers.

text:
The sauce tasted great! With that said, it came out watery. 

It was my first time making it. Preparation was super easy. I used frozen breasts and think that is where I went wrong. I cooked on low for 8hrs with the sauce already in the pot from the beginning. The water from the frozen breasts mixed with the sauce ruining the consistency.

Next time I will just cook the breasts in the pot with chicken broth.  Then drain water, shred chicken, and add bbq sauce and cook for another hour or so.

text:
Very good.  I used already defrosted chicken breasts.  Would not use frozen meat in the slow cooker.  It would cause the food to stay in the "danger zone" temperature too long!  Definitely use a good quality bbq sauce.  Also, definitely shred the chicken 30-60 minutes before the end of the cooking cycle.  The chicken soaks up the sauce and it creates the texture of shredded bbq chicken.  Thickens it up too.

country:
None
text:
We loved this! I only had 3 chicken breasts so I adjusted the recipe and just eyeballed the measurements. There was a little too much liquid left after cooking on low for 8 hours so I shredded the chicken and continued cooking on high with the lid OFF for around 30 minutes. Leaving the lid off allows liquid to evaporate and the sauce thicken. I would do it this way again rather than use less BBQ sauce because the result was heavenly.  Also, my chicken wasn't frozen because I believe using frozen can be unsafe.

text:
I thought that this was pretty good!  I used fresh chicken breasts and cooked on high for about two hours.  I noted that the sauce seemed a bit thin, so I added two heaping tablespoons of cornstarch.  I also shredded as much of the chicken as was cooked, then lowered the cooking temp to "low" for another hour.  I then shredded the rest of the chicken, and served!  Four of the six kids who ate it loved it and asked for seconds.  The other two are notoriously picky, so they are really not good judges anyway. :)

country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as the recipe stated, except used a whole bag (2 lbs?) of frozen chicken breasts which equalled about 8 breasts.  I used the Serving Calculator on the site to alter the ingredient amounts.  I love that feature!  I defrosted the chicken first, then added the chicken and sauce in my crockpot and refrigerated it over night.  I cooked it on high for 4 hours, then removed the chicken and all the sauce into a separate bowl.  After shredding the chicken, I added it back to the crock pot with about half the sauce and cooked it on low for another 2 hours.  The remaining sauce I served on the side for those who wanted more.  It was very easy and very tasty!

this was great—i'm relatively new to the slow cooker, but it's my favorite thing i've made so far. i used fresh chicken, cooked for 3 hours on high, took it out to shred, then back in for another hour. i did add about a TBSP of flour as, based on other reviews, i was nervous about the thickness, although i don't know that it needed it. to get to five stars, next time i will either cut down on the brown sugar, but that's really just a matter of taste. i will definitely be making this again soon!

text:
This was an amazing recipe! I did not take the time to read the reviews before I made the BBQ chicken so I did throw the chicken in frozen. With that said before I shredded the chicken I drained about half of the juice then added about a half cup more of BBQ sauce. All said and done it did not have too much liquid and tasted AMAZING! I will try to make it next time with unfrozen chicken, but if you start the recipe before you read the reviews don't worry about what you've read... just drain it a bit before you throw the shredding chicken back in the mix. Also, I used KC Masterpiece so I think the thick style BBQ that it is helped out significantly.

text:
Per another reviewer: I season chicken with garlic powder, a little salt and pepper add a can of chicken broth and throw in crockpot and cook on low for about 6 to eight hours. When you get home, drain grease shred chicken and pour rest of ingredients (plus 1 tsp liquid smoke, 4 cloves of garlic minced and 1/2 a cup of minced onions) over chicken for about an hour to blend flavors.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very easy and yummy recipe!!  Although, it really all depends on the BBQ sauce you use.  My chicken was a little sweeter then I would have liked it, so next time I will probably get a spicy BBQ sauce.  But I love throwing everything in the crock-pot for a delicious dinner, SO EASY!!  I did put some flour in towards the end of cooking the chicken because my sauce was very thin, I wanted it to be thick.  But still turned out great!  I just put the chicken on toasted hamburger buns and my hubby loved it!

I have a lot of shredded chicken left over, which is great!!  I plan on making a BBQ Chicken Pizza with the leftovers tonight, YUM!!

Great recipe if you want a healthier version of pulled pork sandwiches!!

text:
My husband could not stop raving about this dinner!  As soon as he walked in the house after work he kept saying how delicious it smelled. I used Sweet Baby Rays honey barbecue sauce and I also added liquid smoke, chopped onion, cayenne pepper and garlic cloves as other readers did.  I only used 3 chicken breasts and my sauce was not runny at all.  In fact it was really thick. I do not know if it was the barbecue sauce but, it was fantastic!  I used Belles hamburger bun recipe and this was a great hit.  Will definitely continue using this all the time.  Thank you for the great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very good. Just throw some chicken in the crockput with enough water to cover it and cook on medium for a few hours. When it's somewhat cooked, shred or cube the chicken and put it back in the crockpot with all the sauce for a few more hours. I highly recommend using Sweet Baby Ray's sauce and eliminating the sugar as there is plenty in most sauces already. I also put in about 2 teaspoons garlic powder and 1 tablespoon crushed red pepper to enhance the flavor but you should only do so if you like things spicier. I prefer Bragg's Amino Acid to the Worcestershire sauce but it's fine either way. This great served on potato buns with some scalloped potatoes on the side.

text:
I have been asked again and again for this recipe! So fast, easy, and delicious! I disagree with the serving count. I halve this recipe for our little family of three, and still end up with quite a bit of leftovers. Excellent as written, but after making several times, I now sub in lite Italian dressing, Splenda brown sugar blend, and Lea & Perrins Chicken "Marinade" in place of the Worcestershire. And I always use Baby Ray's BBQ sauce for the best flavor. AWESOME!!

text:
I loved this recipe. So easy and so tasty! I cooked the chicken with chopped onion, minced garlic, and some chicken broth for about 6 hours. Once the chicken was cooked thru and falling apart I dumped the broth/onion/garlic, turned off the slow cooker and added the bbq (orig. jack daniels), dressing, sugar, and worcestershire. Let this combine for about 2 to 2.5 hours. Made baked beans on the side and served on hoagie rolls. Very good!

Very good!  I did some things different. I defrosed my chicken first and added 4 cloves minced garlic and 1/2 a chopped onion. Cooked on low for about 4 hours then shredded chicken and put it back in for a hour. Came out great! Use brown sugar also and added red pepper. My husband ate it on a hoggie and I had mine in a backed potato. Tomorrow for lunch I will be putting it in a southwest salad. I love how many different things you can do with this recipe. Also I thought there was too much sauce in it and that is why I shredded it and put it back in but it covered it completly. Amazing!

text:
I am always hesitant trying new things because my family does not like to try new things, but this was wonderful and everyone loved it. I didn't have worcestershire sauce so I didn't add it. I cooked the chicken on high for about 2-3 hours and was concerned because the sauce was so runny. But when I turned the crockpot down to low, the sauce did thicken up some. I pulled the chicken apart and let it sit for about 1 hour on keep warm. The chicken was so moist.  It was not dry liked pork can be. Great balance of flavors. I had minimal leftovers but fed 8 people and my husband had 3 sandwiches. A great change for chicken.

country:
None
text:
Scrumptious BBQ chicken sandwiches and SOOOO simple! I made a double portion to take to a pot luck and served with mini buns... they were absolutely delicious! I cooked mine on low for at least 8 hrs. Took the chicken out a couple of hrs. before it was done to shred it and then added it back to the crockpot for the last 2 hrs. of cook time. It does seem like too much liquid at first, but once the chicken is shredded, it soaks up and absorbs the juices nicely and has the perfect consistency to sit on a bun. I used "Good Seasons" Italian dressing and for the BBQ Sauce, "Open Pit" - original flavor, (because of the addition of the brown sugar, I didn't want to go with a sweet tasting sauce). These brands turned out great results, but use whatever your personal favorites are.

text:
Our family loves this recipe. I usually follow the directions to a "T" (but use fresh chicken breasts instead of frozen).  The last time I made these, I cooked the chicken first in the crockpot by it self (with some stock) for about 2 hours, shredded it, then added the rest of the ingredients and cooked again for an hour so the flavors had a chance to meld. I liked this way better because the barbecue sauce was more "fresh" tasting. Sometimes my slowcooker gives a faint "burned" taste to the bbq sauce if cooked the entire time and I'm not a big fan of that. Anyways, fabulous blend of flavors.

text:
This recipe was so unbelievably easy I didn't think it could possibly turn out...I was wrong!  My family thought the chicken was so tender and flavorful that this recipe now trumps my barbecued pulled pork!  I followed the recipe exactly as written (using either Sweet Baby Rays, Jack Daniels, or Sticky Fingers sauce) but also threw in some chopped sweet onions.  After I shredded the chicken, I ladled some of the juices over it; then took a ladleful of the cooking juices and mixed it with some more of the bottled barbecue sauce to make a thicker sauce for serving.  We used the chicken in flour tortilla wraps with lettuce and some shredded cheddar.  Delicious - thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a good starter! I didn't have italian dressing so I combined two BBQ sauces - Sweet Baby Ray's regular and Carolina Treet (I AM in NC and love the vinegar - mustardy style sauce). That gave it the right tang. Also added onion and garlic and red pepper flakes per some reviews. I had boneless skinless chicken thighs and cooked them from fresh, not frozen. It didn't take any time at all, maybe an hour and a half at a low boil (mediumish) on the stove, then shredded the thighs and stewed for another hour. Fantastic! Just the right amount of hot and sweet, very tender, not too liquidy at all. Shredding the chicken really does soak up the sauce - also using thicker sauces helps. Just FYI, dark meat chicken actually makes good stewed/BBQ style dishes and doesn't dry out as quickly as chicken breasts sometimes do. Thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!
I did NOT use frozen chicken, and I used skinless chicken breasts WITH the bone.  I find that cooking them on the bone makes them much juicier.  
I sliced one large sweet yellow onion, and put this over the bottom of the slow cooker.  I laid the bone-in chicken breasts on top of the onions, and seasoned all well with kosher salt and lemon pepper.  Also sprinkled a couple of cloves of minced garlic over the chicken.  Ended up using an 18 oz. bottle of bbq sauce, used recipe amounts of dressing, worcestershire, and br sugar, and also added a little apple cider vinegar to the sauce.
Cooked on low for about 5 hours, and then pulled chicken off the bone (it literally all just fell apart), and shredded the meat into the sauce.  Served the meat right out of the cooker, piled up on toasted whole wheat buns with melted cheddar/chipotle cheese.
YUM!

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe a few weeks ago and making it again tonight. I have no hesitation that my boyfriend will be surely surprised when he gets home from work. The first time I made it he said it was just like the chicken his grandma used to make him as a kid. I did take into account the other users' tips, such as: THE SAUCE IS THE KEY! you HAVE to use a good sauce to make it work, I used Bulls Eye Chicken and Rib and also added a table spoon of honey in the mixtures. I used *thawed chicken breasts and placed them in the slowcooker all in the center, then poured my goopy mixture overtop. I left it for about 3 o 4 hours on high. it turned out so sweet and sticky. Also be sure to get good quality chicken (this is not meant how it sounds, but) the bigger the breast the better, I found, smaller ones in my slow cooker got a little rubbery on the edges. All in all a great recipe, if you follow it to a tee, this is really great chicken but I do have one tip to follow: doucle the mixture as the chicken will be completely coated and makes for really tender chicken, along with a leftover sauce to go over your rice, potatoes or other side dish.

text:
I always follow a new recipe “as is” the first time I try and then add/omit ingredients if it’s a keeper. This is a keeper! Like other reviews, thought combo of dressing and bbq sauce was odd but it’s so good! I agree strongly with using nicer bbq sauce. It does make a difference in all recipes. 

I took advice from another review to cook chicken in broth then add sauce later to prevent burning. Perfect! Used three large chicken breast, seasoned with garlic powder, onion powder, + meat tenderizer. Added two cups of Swanson broth (cooked on Low for 4 hours) Pot auto sets to warm afterwards. It was perfect when returning home. (Six hours total) dumped the broth, shredded the chicken and added in the sauce. Set back to Low for 1 hour. No watery sauce here! Delicious!

Display Name:
KinyaMcNeil

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simply Delicious and a Keeper!

This recipe was very good and I had no issues with the thickness of the sauce.  I did follow the advice of others and made some tweaks.  I used 6 boneless, skinless fresh chicken breast halves.  Seasoned them in the slow cooker with staple seasonings (Adobo, Garlic Powder, Onion Powder, White Pepper), chopped up in chunks and added red onion, green pepper, orange pepper, red pepper and Garlic cloves.  I then poured Chicken Broth into the pot until all items were covered.  Cooked on High for 3 hours.  Drained the liquid from the pot and removed vegetables.  Used two forks to shred the chicken then poured the ingredients as directed for the sauce into the pot.  Cooked for ½ hour more on high.

I used an 18oz bottle of Sweet Baby Ray’s Sweet Vidalia BBQ sauce and a little bit of Stick Fingers (don’t remember the type) along with Wishbone’s Italian Dressing.

I did need to add some more Adobo, white salt and Italian seasoning in the end to counter the sweetness of the sauce.  Maybe next time I won’t use a Sweet BBQ sauce along with the brown sugar.

Oh...and I added bacon strips on top of the sandwiches...delicious!!

text:
I made this two nights ago. I only tweaked it based on what I had on hand. I thawed 4 large frozen chicken breasts, placed them in the slow cooker. Added 1/2 cup of Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ Sauce, 1/2 c zesty Italian dressing, 1 cup of double strength chicken stock, 2 tbsp soy sauce and a tbsp brown sugar, 1/2 cup finely chopped onion and 1 clove minced garlic. Cooked 4 hours on high. Shredded and served in soft flour tortillas with grated cheddar etc. Even my picky 6 year old granddaughter wolfed them down! Enough for 2 nights! It was delicious. Thank you for sharing.

text:
So glad we discovered this and that I read the comments. I prepare a ton of chicken as mentioned in the first comment - garlic powder, paprika, and a little chicken broth or water on low for 6-8 hours. Then I shred it all and use it for everything (pizza, enchiladas, stuffed crescent rolls, salads, etc), and of course this recipe. I use sweet baby rays honey bbq and F&E Italian, I don't add brown sugar since the bbq is sweet. I mix that in the bottom of my warm crockpot then mix in shredded chicken until it's not too saucy. I let it warm up while I prepare the salad and rolls or buns. Very good with a slice of cheddar cheese.

text:
I put 4 frozen chicken thighs and 2 frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot with some chicken broth and chopped onion with some salt, pepper and a heavy sprinkle of BBQ rub.  Cooked on low until I got home from work.  Strained the chicken/onion from the broth, pulled off the skin, deboned the thighs and shredded the chicken.  Back into the crock pot with onions and added the BBQ sauce mixture until it was warmed through.  Nice taste of BBQ in the winter - makes me long for the summer...

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a molasses based barbecue sauce (The Shed Barbecue & Blues Joint sauce) and added one sliced red onion and three minced garlic cloves to the recipe. After three hours of cooking on high, I drained most of the liquid and added an additional half bottle of barbecue sauce. I finished cooking an additional hour and it was perfect! Thanks for the recipe. Update: If you make this the prior day to serving, stop cooking at hour three and shred the chicken and DO NOT DRAIN. Then refrigerate the container overnight and the next day cook an additional hour. All of the extra liquid will have been absorbed and you don't need to use more barbecue sauce if you don't want.

THIS CHICKEN IS A GREAT PARTY MEAL.  I more than doubled the recipe and took the advice of another reviewer and cooked the chicken last night in broth, shredded the chicken this morning and we'll be having them in a couple of hours for my sissy's bday celebration.  The chicken tastes phenomenal even cold. I did add some of the chicken broth less the fat (it floats to the top and hardens in the fridge) to the sauce. Rating:

dateLastModified:
2014-07-13T18:00:30.15
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
12615947
Display Name:
Jen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
22
favoritesCount:
741
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
More than an Awesome Recipe! I made this recipe tonight for dinner. I used only 4 good sized frozen chicken breasts, washing and trimming them first. The only changes I made was obviously to the sauce. I used about 3 tablespoons more of brown sugar, 8oz. zesty Italian dressing, 18oz. Sweet Baby Rays Cola BBQ sauce, a dash of adobo, a dash of adobe pepper sauce, salt and pepper to taste. Half way through the cooking time I took the chicken out and shredded it, then returned it to the pot and stirred it into the sauce. The total cooking time was 5 hours on low in my crock pot. After the 5 hours I lowered the setting to warm for about 1 hour then shut the pot off. The more you let the mixture sit it will soak up all that lovely juice. I served the BBQ chicken on Hawaiian Sweet Rolls with coleslaw on or off to the side. Me and My better half loved it. Try it! I know you will love this easy tasty recipe too!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-07-10T15:04:06.633
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
7454115
Display Name:
cailoisa
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good as is, but I had to make a few changes. I rubbed salt, pepper, onion and garlic powders, and paprika under the skin of unfrozen chicken (food safety courses teach not to use frozen meat in slow cookers because it spends too much time in the 'danger zone'). Then I placed the chicken  in the cooker on top of balls of foil and added about 1/3 c water and some liquid smoke to the bottom. After 4 hours on low I lifted the chicken out, removed the foil, and drained the juices, then shredded the chicken and returned it to the cooker with sauces and cooked another hour on low. A couple notes: whenever I make this I add extra chicken initially, then set it aside before adding sauces so I already have perfectly cooked chicken for salad or whatever else. And if you don't have Italian dressing, you can just do what I did, after topping with BBQ, drizzle with olive oil, red wine vinegar (or any wine vinegar), lemon juice, and parsley and oregano to taste. Finally, if you use a sweet barbeque sauce (I used honey barbeque) do NOT add the additional brown sugar, it makes it far too sweet. Don't be put off by the BBQ and Italian dressing combo, it makes an all around crowd pleaser that was enjoyed by everyone in my family.

city:

country:
None
text:
Love this recipe and make it often.  The first time I followed it exactly and was not thrilled with the results.  It was way too sweet for me.  The BBQ sauce I used was sweet baby rays original so maybe thats why.  I had to add a lot of salt to cut the sweetness and I also added crush red pepper flakes.  Now when I make it I only do 1 tbs of the brown sugar.  I also add about 1tbs of the crushed red pepper flakes and about 1tsp of salt.    Also a reviewer commented on that the chicken should be thawed not frozen- I have made it both ways just because 1 time I only had fresh chicken.  It works fine either way. If its thawed you just cut back on the cooking time.  Also, this recipe does not address actually making this BBQ.  I check the chicken when I think it is cooked through and take it out and shred it and then place it back into the crock pot to simmer another 30-45 minutes to soak everything up.

I am new to allrecipes, and came across this recipe while just looking around. I used pork tenderloin instead of chicken, with Stubbs BBQ sauce, and substituted vidalia onion dressing for the Italian. Cooked the defrosted pork in the crockpot on high for 3 hours, and then pulled it apart using two forks. It came apart effortlessly. I took some of the excess BBQ sauce from the crock to be used if needed when building the sandwich. I put the pork back into the remaining sauce and continued cooking for an additional hour on low setting.  Served on a nice kaiser roll with some red leaf lettuce, red onion, and a side of applesauce. It was perfect. Sorry to change the ingredients, but I used what I had out at the time. I will try it with chicken next, and I  am certain it will be just as good. Love the site. Thanx.

text:
This got absolutely rave reviews!!!  I actually used this recipe to cook the rabbits my wife and I raise, as follows: two whole rabbits, meat cut off the bone; browned briefly in bacon grease; placed in slow cooker with the sauce exactly as written (yes, using good BBQ sauce); cooked one hour on high and four hours on low (just due to time restriction, not any specific strategy); shredded meat with forks and left in slow cooker on warm; served on buns with coleslaw and pickles available to put on top.  This was one of my very favorite rabbit recipes yet, and I will make it again and again, just like this!!

text:
I totally forgot to put the Worcestershire sauce in...DOH! Ok so I used Stubb's Hickory BBQ Sauce which is made with molasses and just about the best most expensive BBQ sauce you can get at any local store in these parts. I used a Kraft brand zesty style robust Italian dressing, Put on high for 2 hours then low for 3, then separated the chicken and put it back in for another hour and a half. This was SO good! I will add the Worcestershire sauce next time though. I bought a 24 pack of sliders and there was enough to fill up 18 generously. I added a slice of red onion and some chipotle white cheddar to the sliders as well. The family was happy. So will make again. Probably double it next time though. Leftovers can be used for a large BBQ chicken pizza. This stuff undoubtedly goes fast!

text:
This is AWESOME!  I've made it with Sweet Baby Ray's a few times and today I'm trying it with the Jack Daniel's Spicy BBQ!  I put raw chicken breasts in the crock pot and cover it with chicken broth for a couple of hours on low.  Then I drain the broth out as per the other reviewers suggestion and took a pair of tongs to it to shred it.  Super easy.  I then sauté my onion till it looks translucent and coat them with brown sugar.  throw that in the pot, then do a couple cloves of garlic and throw that in with some bell peppers.  I, myself, am not a big fan of chicken, but the BF loves it as he thinks its better than pork (i disagree) :P But the BF gets what he wants and he LOVES IT!  Always takes the leftovers to work.  I'm gonna try it with baked potato, that sounds yum!  :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe over and over-it is one of my "go to" dinners. I have changed a few things along the way to suit my family's preferences. First,I cook the chicken only with garlic powder, powdered hickory seasoning and salt. When the chicken is done (4 hours on high for a BIG batch (I made 7 lbs this time), I use a baster to remove 2/3 of the chicken broth/juice,and set it aside. I then add barbecue sauce, and the recommended amount of vinegar and Worcestershire sauce to taste,but I skip the sugar because I don't like it sweet. Finally, I add back some of the broth, but not too much or it gets watery. What a great, easy dinner for company too.Serve with coleslaw-mandatory!

I loved this recipe! I made it yesterday! I had it in the crockpot for 8 hours on low. When it finished I shredded the chicken with a fork and put the lid back on to let it sit in the pot for another hour when the crockpot was not on (just warm from all that cooking it did). And I would recommended putting 3 cups (instead of 1.5 cups that it calls for) of Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ Sauce. It makes a lot but great for leftovers or a small party with friends! I want to say it serves about 20 when you are making them for BBQ pulled chicken sandwiches.

text:
I made this for my son's birthday party, and almost everyone who went asked for the recipe! I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ, and before the last hour was up, shredded the chicken and it absorbs so much more sauce. At first I thought it was too runny, but after doing this, it came out perfect! I love how simple it is! And leftovers, if you have any, are amazing. My husband had me make this twice the first week I tried it. I will keep this recipe forever. And easy to adjust with different flavored dressings and BBQ sauces. I've found it's very forgiving for substituting. TRY IT!!!! Nobody could believe how simple it is! Put it in, and come back the last hour to shred and enjoy!

text:
Great recipe!  I make it just like it says, using Kraft "Zesty Italian, fat free" dressing, and "Sweet Baby Ray's 'Sweet Vidalia Onion'" BBQ sauce.  Sometimes I add a little more dressing than what it calls for.  Also, if I need more BBQ sauce, I typically add the SBR "Sweet and Spicy" sauce, to give it a little more kick.  

Really easy recipe.  I cook on low for maybe 4-5 hours and then shred the chicken and let it go another couple hours. 

We've made up several batches of this for my daughters 1st birthday party.  We've cooked it up, put it in bags, and have a few frozen ready to go.  Hopefully we can just thaw them and pop them in the crockpot on the day of the party!  Haven't tried freezing this before so I hope it turns out ok....I'm sure it will.

text:
LOVE this recipe. What a great use of chicken breasts and so easy. First time I made this was for camping (prefer slow cooker for camping so I can have a meal ready after a full day of play). Pre-measured salad dressing, sugar and Worcestershire and put in baggie. When we got to camp I just threw in all in the crock. Our preferred bbq sauce is Dinosaur. When you open the crock at the end of cook time you're going to see a whole lot of liquid. No worries. Grab a couple of serving forks and shred away, the liquid will be absorbed in no time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/42038.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a large crowd and it went over really well!  I used 25 (thawed) skinless, boneless chicken thighs.  Since I was cooking so many I doubled all of the ingredients, in addition to adding some minced garlic.  I actually used 3 bottles of bbq sauce.  I divided the 25 thighs and put half in my crock pot and half in my dutch oven.  After doubling the ingredients - it makes a lot -  I put ONLY half of it, and divided it among the 2 pots.  I put the crock pot on high and the oven on 300 degrees and cooked both for 3 hours.  After 3 hours, it looked about done and was very watery.  I removed most of the liquid from both pots, put the meat from the dutch oven into the crock pot and dumped the remaining bbq mixture into the crock pot.  Cooked on low for another 1/2 hour.  I didn't need to shred it as it literally fell apart.  It was delicious!  Great dish to make for a crowd!

text:
Very tender chicken with a great taste that I attribute to the italian dressing which really makes the chicken stand out. I vamped the recipe a little bit to suit my own taste. I added 2 tsp's of liquid smoke and a tsp of creole seasoning. Its vital that you use good bbq sauce not just store brand. I used Odom's hickory and brown sugar so i could omit the brown sugar called for in the recipe which would have made it a little to sweet for me. I enjoy a more spicy bbq. Other than those minor things however it turned out great and was super easy to put together.

text:
Used 5 fresh boneless skinless chicken breasts.  Put on high for 3 hours with 1/2 dinosaur brand bbq sauce and chicken broth.  After 3 hours took out most of the sauce, shredded, and kept in some juice for the taste of the drippings, and poured out remainder of the bbq mixture.  Set crock on low for additional hour. Lastly, turned crock on warm and let it "soak the juices up".  Served with cole slaw  Great for memorial day. Loved no fuss and spent time with family instead m To quote my husband, "I don't think there's a person out there that wouldn't like this". Defintely making again.

country:
None
text:
Amazingly, all my kids liked this (and one of them hates BBQ). Used Sweet Baby Ray's Honey Barbeque Sauce. Will definitely add into our regular rotation. Top with thinly sliced red onion and coleslaw and you can't go wrong!

What I did based on some reviews:

I’ve heard not to use frozen meat in a crock pot, so use fresh/thawed chicken breasts. 
Put chicken breasts in crockpot, sprinkled on salt and pepper and garlic powder, and poured in a cup or two of chicken broth (didn’t cover the chicken - it was just enough to cover about 2/3 of the chicken).
Cooked on high for 3 hours.
Shred chicken.
Put ingredients at above amounts in with the shredded chicken and cook on low for 1 more hour. 

***For the 7 chicken breasts I cooked, I nearly doubled the sauce recipe...

text:
This recipes is awesome, of course made some changes per other reviewers.  I did everything as the recipe states, and added 1/2 an onion to the sauce.  Cooked thawed breasts for about 5 hours on low, took the chicken out to shred.  While the chicken was out, I added about 2 tbsp. Wondra (gravy flour) to the sauce because it was very watery, whisked for about 3-5 min. Once sauce was thickened added chicken back to cook for about another hour on low( it will soak up all the juice once shredded).  Turned out amazing! Also made plenty of leftovers!

country:

text:
I have made this almost every week since trying it out.  My husband and I both LOVE it.  He needs to take in a lot of protein (and very few carbs) each week and this is a very tastey way to have chicken.  We leave out the sugar and don't miss it.  I've used frozen and fresh chicken and have even used some of each in a pinch.  I find that the frozen takes longer to cook, so the low setting for longer works better.  After I make this up I weigh it into portions, refridgerate some and freeze the rest.  I recommend trying out different BBQ sauces for some variety.  We like Gringo Jack's and I've been using Ken's Light Italian dressing.  Wonderful!

None
text:
This recipe is amazing! It's so simple, and I've never received more compliments on any other dish I've ever made.

The only suggestion I would add is to shred the chicken using two forks about an hour or two before it is done cooking. This gives it more of a pulled pork type of feel, and the bbq mixture soaks into the chicken even more thoroughly after it is shredded.

Also, if you like a little kick, I add some cayenne pepper powder to the bbq mixture.

5 stars for taste AND for easiness!

country:
None
text:
These sandwiches are delicious! I didn't add the brown sugar because I didn't have any, but honestly I don't think it really needed it! I wouldn't have wanted it any sweeter. I only used about 2/3 of the bottle of barbecue sauce which was plenty. I also added some chopped onion to the slow cooker, and added some lettuce to the sandwich. It only needed about 6 hours on low and the chicken shredded very easily. Like others have said, stir the chicken after shredding and let sit for a couple minutes to let the shredded pieces absorb the sauce. 
Served with some spicy baked beans. Delicious!

I am new to cooking, but this recipe was so easy!! My boyfriend and I make it all the time and love the left overs. I took some of the advice from the other reviewers and shred the chicken an hour before it is done to soak up some of the bbq sauce. I also leave the top off the last hour. IF you don't have worcestershire sauce on hand it tastes good with out it. My boyfriend made this for his work and it went fast we thought we'd have left overs and didn't. Love Love Love this recipe! Thanks Zanne Tastic :)

I made this receipe twice. It was delish...just enough spice to offset some of the sweetness.

text:
Excellent! I was skeptical that this few ingredients could deliver a yummy barbecue chicken but wow was I surprised! 
I agree with another reviewer that the sauce seems a bit runny until after you shred the meat and let it soak up a bit.  Served this on buns for the crew and over a salad with for myself! Super yum!
I did season the chicken breasts with garlic powder and seasoning salt prior to placing in crock pot & added a Tbsp of balsamic to the sauce at the end before adding to the pot because it seemed a bit sweet to me.  Perfect & easy! Great combo for a weeknight meal!

I needed shredded chicken for sandwiches so I cooked the boneless skinless chicken pieces in the crock pot first. I don't like sweet bbq sauce so I did not buy the honey sweetened kind.  I used Budweiser Original.  After tasting before adding the sugar, it did need the full amount of sugar because of the tartness of the Italian dressing.  It was good, not great.  Guests ate it and were complmentary but no real raves about it.

text:
First time making this and it turned out Amazing!!! I used 3 large fresh chicken breasts and added 3 large cloves garlic minced and a tablespoon of maple smokehouse seasoning. Cooked on high for 30 minutes then low for 3 hours, took chicken out shredded (the chicken fell apart perfectly) and added 1 tablespoon flour for last hour. I found it cooked a lot faster than stated possibly my crock pot runs higher than others. Sauce turned out perfect, nice amd thick! We put it on baked potatoes with cheddar cheese and sour cream. We are having it for lunch today on a bun with diced onion and pepperjack cheese. I'm excited!!! This will be on the menu very often and I'm sure it will be a hit at our next family get together.

I wasn't so sure about this, I just didn't think it sounded like anything special.  But I have to admit I was very pleasantly surprised.  I followed the recipe exactly.  Threw my chicken breasts in straight from the freezer and cooked it on high for exactly 4 hours.  The chicken shredded beautifully and I served it on sandwich rolls. It would also be good served over rice or mashed potatoes.  I definitely recommend using a savory or spicy bbq sauce, not sweet.  Or if you do, just omit the brown sugar.  This was perfect for a busy school night family dinner!

Delicious! I made this for a group camping trip. It was phenomenal! I made it the afternoon before we left. I shredded the chicken and put it back in the slow cooker for a couple more hours. I had no problem with runny sauce - the shredded chicken really does soak up the sauce. Baby Ray's and Kraft Italian worked well together. Adults loved it, kids loved it. I'm making it again for our next camping trip and I'll be making it frequently! Thanks for the great recipe!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading all the reviews, I made a few changes. First, I put frozen chicken breasts in slow cooker on high for 3 hours with some chicken broth, worcestershire and a little liquid smoke. Then I drained the broth, shredded the chicken and added a bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's original bbq sauce, 2 Tbs Worcestershire, only 1/4 cup of Italian dressing, NO brown sugar, 1 tsp minced garlic and added half of a finely diced red onion and finished it on low for another hour. The chicken was very moist, shredded easily and had very good flavor. I only gave 4 stars because I changed it a bit. I will make this again with my modifications.

text:
I made it as is with top of the line BBQ sauce.  I found the Italian sauce to be too strong, and somewhat bland.  

After at least tasting it the original way, I almost completely changed it by adding a lot of spices and worcestershire sauce, and a touch of soy sauce.  This helped a lot.  After that, it was definitely good.  But it seems like a lot of work for something I can just get out of the BBQ sauce itself.  I wouldn't make this again... not that it was bad, but it just didn't stand out from anything I can get from the store.

This is fabulous.  I love BBQ sauce, so I didn't figure I would hate this, and I really liked it a lot.  I'm making it today for the second time.  I used 3 chicken breasts both times but kept the rest of the recipe the same and I didn't feel it was too saucy.  I also didn't have watery sauce like others have said.  I served it atop slices of bread open-faced since we didn't have buns and it was delicious.  Today we'll have it on wheat buns.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's (my favorite) and home-made Italian dressing.

I've made this on numerous occassions with only 2 adds - 1 to 2 teaspoons of hickory smoke and a little red chili sauce for a little spice.  This work great as sliders.  I preferred dinner rolls over the mini hamburger buns.  Dinner rolls with a little melted butter and slightly toasted with shredded lettuce and sliced tomatoes makes for a perfect game day meal or just any type of meal for a large crowd.  I did this on a game day and everyone loved making their sliders as I continuously toasted the rolls and yelled "Hot Buns, come and get it" as I took the rolls out of the oven.  Mmmm mmm good!!

text:
I used unfrozen chicken breasts and still cooked for 7 hours on low; worked out just fine!  I found the brown suger and Italian dressing made the sauce a little too sweet for my taste, so I ended up adding extra BBQ and Worcestershire, as well as some hot sauce.  In addition, I added pepper, crushed garlic, onion powder, paprika, and coriander when I put the chicken and sauce in, and I added a little flour about 30min before I was done cooking to help the sauce thicken.

text:
This seemed a little bland on it's own. The second time I cooked it, I added 3 minced garlic gloves, a sliced white onion, 2 tbsp of taco seasoning, a diced bell pepper, a small habanero (seeded and finely diced) and a couple of shakes of tabasco. It countered the sweetness of the bbq sauce and brown sugar nicely. If you like SPICY barbeque, these changes to the recipe might interest you.

text:
ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC!! I unfortunately only got left overs, but they were still to die for! I called my husband to ask him how dinner was and he was in heaven! I did about 5 chicken breasts, about 16 oz of BBQ sauce, 1/3 c. of brown sugar and about 2 tbsp of worcestershire sauce. I put it all in the crock pot (breast frozen) and left it on high for about 7 or 8 hours until it was just falling apart. I will definitely be making this regularly! It is so easy just to throw it all in there. Although, next time I might make my own BBQ sauce (Bar-B-Que Sauce on this site) to omit a lot of the sugar and high fructose corn syrup. And I might try substituting honey for the brown sugar next time.

I used some chicken tenderloins I had in the freezer, and for the BBQ sauce, I used 1/2 bottle of Jack Daniels Spicy Homestyle BBQ Sauce and 1/2 bottle of Kraft Spicy Chipotle. The chicken turned out tender and very flavorful.  Like the other reviewers, I had a lot of sauce left, but it made a great "au jus" dip for the buns. Thanks for the recipe, and I will definitely make it again!

text:
Love this recipe but I've modified it a bit.  I use a little less brown sugar, add a large sweet onion and a tablespoon or two of liquid smoke.  Like previous posters, I also use non frozen chicken and cook on high for 3 to 3 1/2 hours.  At 2 1/2 hours, use 2 forks to start pulling the chicken apart and then stir well.  Delicious!

I have made this recipe multiple times, and each time I make it, I remember just how good it is!! The smell this slow cooker chicken makes as it is cooking in incredible. This was REALLY good!  I used Jack Daniels bbq sauce and Newman's Italian dressing.  I followed the recipe exactly cooking on high for 4-5 hours. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was such an easy recipe to make.  I ended up using the advice of several to make mine.  I did use 5 frozen chicken breasts.  Before I added the sauce mixture I finely chopped a white onion,  I seasoned the chicken with garlic powder, pepper and Lowry's and I also added about a cup of reduced sodium, all natural chicken broth.  I then followed the recipe for the BBQ sauce mixture.  My husband bought KC Masterpiece regular BBQ sauce...that seemed to work fine.  I also didn't have enough time so I cooked all of this on high for 3 hours.  After the 3 hours, I took out the chicken and shredded it with two forks.  I also took some of the BBQ sauce from my slow cooker and placed it in my glass pyrex measuring cup and added some flour to thicken the remaining sauce.  I used a wisk to remove the lumps...this is how my mom makes her gravy too...and returned the thicker sauce to the pot....I continued wisking to ensure the thicker sauce circulated.  I returned the shredded chicken to the pot and cooked an additional hour.  My husband thought the chicken was a little over cooked so I would suggest cutting that 4th hour into half an hour.  I brushed the tops of our whole wheat potato bread hamburger bunswith an olive oil, garlic pwder and touch of salt mixture and placed the buns in the broiler until they were a tad warm and toasty.  I will devinitly make this recipe again!  DELISH!

text:
Tasty! This one's a keeper. I used 6 fresh chicken breast halves. I put them in a 4-5 qt oblong slow cooker (not certain exactly how large is) and followed the recipe to make the sauce. I used Cookie's BBQ sauce and super cheap Italian dressing. I poured the sauce over the top and cooked them on low for 3 hours (they were fully cooked at this point), removed the chicken breasts, shredded them, then returned them to the slow cooker with the sauce and cooked on low for an additional hour. At the three hour mark, the sauce was runny and the chicken was very juicy but a bit flavorless. Almost immediately after the meat was shredded and combined with the sauce, the concoction was perfect! I served it on hamburger buns tonight, and plan to try it over both sweet potatoes and Idaho potatoes later in the week. YUM!!!

text:
I wasn't impressed. I used Famous Dave's BBQ sauce, which has worked well for me in beef slow cooker recipes. But the sauce for this came out watery. I added some flour to thicken it up, shredded the meat and put it back in to soak up the sauce, plus added a little extra BBQ sauce near the end, but it still wasn't enough to make the chicken taste like barbecue. Plus I used fresh breasts; my guess is that it would have been even more watery with frozen. Maybe I should have slow cooked the chicken, drained the pot, then added the BBQ sauce for the last hour, as suggested by another reviewer. The chicken was nice and tender, so I'll definitely try another chicken recipe in the future. But this wasn't the one for barbecue.

city:
