None
country:
None
text:
This recipe definately has some good flavor but I only gave it 3 stars because there is a lot of room for improvement. I love how basic the ingredients are but adding more will help with the taste. First it is kinda sweet so I would recommend using either a more tangy bbq sauce or just cutting out the brown sugar all together since its really not needed. Also cut the chicken into pieces before cooking because the meat tends to get dry in the center. I also added chopped onion and garlic and I would also try it with some pineapple. I served it over rice instead of a baked potato and prefer it that way. Good recipe but my variation is the only way I would eat it again.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved the recipe and used only 3 chilled boneless chicken breast freshly bought from the supermarket. Everything else was kept rather closed to the recipe; except I sliced a large onion, julienned a carrot to put on the bottom of chicken breast for added veggies. I also added 1 tbsp of cider vinegar to the sauce mixture to enhance the flavour. I did listen to others' advice and invested in high quality sauce by using Hunt's Extra-Thick Honey Hickory Barbeque Sauce (coz Sweet Baby Ray's not available in our place). Cook on HIGH for 1 hour (with 1/2 hour side turning of each chicken breast to avoid hardened meat, just in case) and another 2 1/2 hour of cooking on SLOW. I also shredded the chicken 1/2 hour prior to completion time and added the mixture of 1 tbsp of corn flour + water like others to ensure thickened sauce. The meat taste wonderfully tender after sauce absorption and our whole house smelled extremely good, like others’ too...   Both of us were surprised by this uniquely flavourful supper and I brought to work for breakfast the next day to be served with high-grain bun! It tastes even better than yesterday as I am eating now and I can’t wait to get back for the leftover in the fridge….   Thank you very much for this super-easy recipe which only requires less than 10 minutes of preparation time !)

This is the greatest no fuss crock pot recipe I have found yet.  I will suggest to do the longer cook time on low.  I have done both and found that the 8 hour low cook time provides a much deeper flavor.  You can get away with 4 hours on high in a pinch.  I was quite surprised at how much we all enjoyed the chicken over a baked potato. I am thinking of putting liquid smoke in next time!

Just tried this last night and it was GREAT!! I only used 4 defrosted boneless skinless chicken breasts and used a little less of the other ingredients. I reserved half the sauce mixture, and I stirred that in after shredding and cooked for another 30 minutes on low. It was wonderful!

text:
finally a recipe I followed close enough I can rate!  This was really really good!  I tossed in everything per directions, chicken frozen, and cooked on low for about 5hrs.  Then I shredded everything and, knowing the delicious juices would be thinner than I like, I added about 2T cornstarch (diluted in a little water).  After mixing that in I let everything simmer another hour until my husband got home from work.  Voila!  Minimum effort and big taste!  I didn't fuss with a 'quality' bbq sauce, the 89 cent Aldi brand worked great for me.  You will want to use a brand you already like, as the bbq sauce is by far the dominant (yummy) flavor.  In fact, I may try skipping the other ingredients and only dump in the bbq next time, just to see if I taste a difference.

text:
A good recipe to have on hand.  Perfect recipe for summer when you don't want to heat the kitchen and are rained out from using the grill.  Made the recipe exactly as written with good results.  While I LOVE the convenience of throwing in frozen chicken, I might defrost it a little next time to get rid of some of the water and also the "clotting" of the cooked juices when cooking on high temp.  Serving suggestion for leftovers: BBQ Chicken Wraps with shredded/chopped chicken, a little of the sauce and cheddar microwaved on a tortilla.  Top with chopped cilantro and more sauce.  Delicious quick lunch.

text:
I used organic BBQ sauce and added a dash of apple cider vinegar for some extra tang. The chicken was nicely cooked and moist after only 3 hours on high.  I strained the BBQ liquid, then reduced it a saucepan on medium low.  I further thickened it by adding 1T.cornstarch dissolved in 1-2T. cold water. While stirring, bring it to a boil then simmer for one minute. I stirred in the shredded chicken and served it over brown rice.  Yum! My BBQ-loving husband had 2 helpings. This would be great for potlucks too.

text:
This is maybe my SECOND review ever on this site but I finally decided a recipe was definitely worth talking about. I followed this recipe exact, except I used Splenda Brown Sugar & only used 2 Breasts. My chicken was thawed already so I put it on low cooking, 8 hours, and took it our early, at about 6-1/2 hours (as it was already tender, breaking with a SPOON. Oh, and I used a Lite Barbecue sauce by Kraft, which others said was no good. It wasn't good, it was GREAT. I served it with garlic mashed potatoes using the leftover sauce for a "gravy" and corn on the cob. This was the EASIEST, best tasting chicken I have had in a LONG time, and I make a LOT of great chicken. Mmmm.

text:
This was great!  I was very skeptical about this not turning out to be tender since chicken breasts tend to dry out easily, but they turned out soooo moist!  I cooked them on low for about 5 hours, shredded them and cooked another hour.  I then taste tested the sauce and added some more ingredients to get the taste I wanted.  A lot of people was saying that they didnt like the sauce, but just make it your own.  Get a bbq sauce that you like and add as much or less ingredients that you like to make it fit your own tastes.  I added some garlic, onion powder, brown sugar, and a little more bbq sauce at the end to make it just right.  The next day the left-overs were delicious!  We had these as pulled chicken sandwiches and I served them with the Restaurant Coleslaw recipe on the site.

This was great, but I took the chix breasts (all I had was bone-in, so I had to shred it later) in a can of chix broth, 5-6 garlic cloves and cooked it a cpl hrs on high; but I added 1/2 packet of dry Italian dressing while it cooked, instead of adding the real oily dressing later. Put the chix back in w/ the Sweet Baby Ray bbq, that I only bought today after reading all the comments on it. It was great!  I put a little of the broth in there w/ a cpl shakes of W. sce cooked a cpl more hours on low.  Served on buns like everybody else! Thanks for the great post!

text:
I think the cooking time is far too long for this recipe, because it really dried out the meat when I tried it the first time.  After experimenting a couple of times, I've found that three hours or so on low works just fine.  I also added 1 clove of garlic minced, a dash of tobasco, 1/2 tsp of red pepper flakes, and about a tablespoon of extra Worcestershire sauce for added flavor.  I agree with a couple of other reviewers that the sauce was quite thin, but it worked fine adding some of it to the leftovers because I shredded the remaining chicken and we ate it on buns.  Leftovers were great as chicken BBQ sandwiches, too!

Chicken was excellent, tender and juicy not dry what so ever and just falls apart no knife needed and my husband loves it says it taste like succulent rottisiere style chicken now I did make a few changes, I used about; 1/3 cup of Lawrys Teriyaki marinade, and the Original Kraft BBQ suace, and I didn't have the Worchestshire sauce as called for in orig. recipe so I used A1 Thick and Hearty Steak Sauce and I did use mince garlic to suit my families taste I would recommend others do the same and I used diced green and white onions, Its a great recipe and you don't have to use the fancy stuff, I think what happens with some of the others is you may have to add some liquid(i did about a tablespoon of water) hour or so during cooking to cushion the chicken. I thought this was fantastic.  I'm fairly new to slow cookers, and I had not been all that impressed with how all the pot roast / french dip recipes taste the same, but this was a great surprise!

I made this the other night and it was delicious. I did it as a shredded chicken sandwich. I have to say I was a little leary of using frozen chicken breasts as I have always been told to be sure your chicken is totally thawed before using, however this came out great. It was sweet but my family really enjoyed it. I used Kraft Honey Barbecue sauce. I will definitely use this recipe again. I may try the sauce over chipped ham. Great Easy Recipe! Thanks!
Update 7/20/17 - This has become a family favorite. I omit the Worcestershire  Sauce simply because of personal preference. I like to use Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce.

None
text:
This was delicious as shredded bbq chicken sandwiches. I tasted it before I shredded it and it was very tender and tasty, but much better to shred and throw back into the crock pot with all the juices. A few modifications: I used 8 chicken breast halves, 16 oz. honey bbq sauce, fat free Italian dressing, added 1/2 C. water, used only two T. brown sugar... and probably didnt really need the brown sugar. I added green pepper and onion after about three hours, and it was ready to shred after two more hours. (Actually could have shredded it sooner, but might as well let it keep cooking on low if you have the time.)I was able to take out about two cups of the juice, to reserve for serving.  Really, very, good.

I tripled this recipe and used it to feed lots of hungry truck drivers with BIG appetites.  They loved it.  After letting it cook for 8 hours, I shredded the chicken, emptied everything from the crockpot, gave the crockpot a good scrubdown (the brown sugar burnt to the sides of the pot) and then put all the chicken back in with some added fresh bbq sauce.  I served it on buns and got lots of compliments.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
4/16/19....This was so easy and delicious! I followed the recipe except added a few things as suggested by others. I used 2.5 lbs. Chicken Breasts, 18oz of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce, 1/2 cup Olive Garden's Light Italian Salad Dressing, 1/4 cup brown sugar,  2 Tbsp.  Worcestershire sauce, chopped 1 sweet onion, and 1 green pepper, and 1 teaspoon of Hickory Liquid Smoke. Cooked on High for 4 hours, served with coleslaw, maple/bacon baked beans, and mac & cheese.  Dish was a hit! Will make this again!
-Carol  (Kenny's wife : )

text:
I made this for an event at our middle school and the teachers loved it. When I went during my lunch period it was already gone. I will definitely make again. I used Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and Kraft Zesty Italian dressing. To make sure there wasn't too much liquid, once I had shredded the meat, I removed most of the liquid, then put the chicken back in and added the liquid a little at a time. Turns out I used all of it, but I'd rather be safe than sorry. I used fresh chicken breasts because I much prefer them.

text:
We all like it a lot.  Then I made this for 16 people.  I mixed a big package of boneless thighs with the breasts.  8oz. per person.  I roasted in oven at 280 degrees for three hours. Cooled, shredded meat.  Reduced sauce for a 1/2 hour.  Placed shredded meat in slow cooker, added the sauce and more of the bottled Barb B Que sauce.  Placed on low for 3-4 hours and stirred every hour.

Display Name:
Karen Moore

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1405619.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fella said "I'll eat this every day", so it's definitely going into our keeper box of recipes.   I used a big package of thawed chicken breast tenders.   Only things I changed was to add a couple of good glugs (not a technical measurement, I know) of apple cider vinegar and I also cooked up some chopped onion (maybe about 1/2 a medium onion) and minced garlic (about a tsp of the ready-made minced garlic that comes in a jar).   I cooked it all in my crock pot on high for 2 hours and on low for 3 hours.   I removed the chicken and shredded it with two forks which was super easy to do and then threw the chicken and all the liquid from the crock pot into a regular pot on the stove and simmered uncovered for another hour to so to reduce the sauce and let it absorb into the chicken.   I used Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ sauce and Kraft Zesty Italian salad dressing (in case anyone is curious what brands I keep in my frig)  LOL

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7456940.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Extremely messy, but the flavor was perfect! 

I only used three large chicken breasts, but made the same amount of sauce. ¯\_(?)_/¯

As with many others, I used fresh chicken. I cooked the dish on high for 3 hours, then shredded the chicken, then cooked on high for another 30 minutes and finally gave it 30 minutes on low. The chicken was incredibly tender.

-For the barbecue sauce, I used Jack Daniels hickory, which turned out to be a great flavor for this recipe as it adds some nice smokiness. The recipe itself takes care of the sweetness (brown sugar).
-For the Italian dressing, I used Good Seasons Zesty Italian dressing mix, which is combined with olive oil and vinegar. 
-I also added a full tablespoon of garlic.

We used poppy seed-covered kaiser rolls to complete the sandwich. As I mentioned, it was super messy, but I think that's just the nature of this sandwich!

text:
Was in a hurry, so didn't read any reviews and just made as stated. Well, after 4 hours on High, in the crock pot, the chicken pieces were swimming in a watery brown sauce that had very little bbq flavor ! The frozen chicken had released so much juice !  I had to spoon the sauce out and reduce it by half, on the stove and then put it back in the crock pot with the shredded chicken ! After this extra step the dish was delicious, served over baked potatoes. I used Bulls eye original bbq sauce.
Next time I make t his recipe, I will cook the chicken pieces , in the crock pot, with tiny bit of broth or water and may be some slices of onions and garlic for more flavor. And once the chicken is cooked I would spoon out most of the liquid before adding the sauce.

userID:
7500810
Display Name:
Heidi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/700426.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I have tried dozens of pulled this and pulled that recipes, NONE of which I'd ever make again.  I would definitely make this one again!  After reading a LOT of reviews , this is what I did:  1)  sliced 1/2 of a large Vidalia onion & sliced those in half.  Place on bottom of slow cooker.  2) pressed 3 cloves of garlic and sprinkled on top of onion,  3) Place 3 LARGE, thawed (A MUST) chicken breasts on top,   4) used 12 oz. BBQ sauce (I had KC Masterpiece Private Reserve on hand),  5) based on MANY reviews ONLY used 1/4 C. Italian salad dressing (we only eat Good Seasons!),  6) based on MANY reviews ONLY used 1/8 C. brown sugar,  7) used 2 T. Worcestershire  sauce.  Based on another review cooked on HI for 2 1/2 hrs, shredded, then turned slow cooker to low and cooked for about another 30minutes.   A LOT of reviewers had a problem with dry chicken. 
 I believe it's because they slow cooked it for several hours.  I firmly believe my chicken came out so tender b/c I only cooked for 2 1/2 hrs on HI and then another 30 min after shredding.  I would never cook this for 6-8 hrs! I had NO issue with it being watery like many others did.  I NEVER have good luck with chicken breasts....EVER, but, this came out so perfect!  It's super easy and super fast.  Serve on or off buns with homemade cole slaw (also super easy), veggies & pickles on the side.  This one's a keeper!  Thanks!

text:
I made this in a 5 quart slow cooker with 2 large chicken breasts and 2 boneless skinless chicken thighs.  I used Sweet Baby Rays Hawaiian bbq sauce.  It only took 4 hours on low so check your temps with a meat thermometer. 

I love the fact that it's not just chicken in bbq sauce.   It was slightly sweet and very savory.  Im not a huge fan of bbq sauce alone but the dressing  and sugar took the edge off.  I also added 1/2 cup chopped onions.

This recipe would be perfect for casual parties.   YUM.

text:
I pretty much followed this recipe as it is here and it was really good!  I used Stubb's Hickory Smoke BBQ Sauce, added 4 cloves of minced garlic, and 1 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper to add an extra kick.  I cooked on high for 3.5 hours, pulled out the meat and shredded it, put it back in the pot for an additional 1/2 hour.  If the sauce is too thin for your liking, I would suggest mixing 2 tbsp of cornstarch to 1/4 c cold water and then adding to the sauce for the final 30 minutes of cooking.

text:
this has become my go-to bbq for crock pot meats of any kind. I've made this many times with chicken, beef and pork, with and without worcestershire, and it always turns out great.  I like wishbone Italian for it but have used many others. it's always good. I've gone without brown sugar if I don't have any. but I go just by the recipe if I can. it's always great and there are rarely leftovers. even my picky mother in law asked for the recipe. I make adjustments but I find it annoying when people review about how great they made it their way.  like, yes it could be better with homemade everything but not all people have time and money for homemade bbq,etc. oh, I use sweet baby rays original but have tried others. our family leans to sweet sauce. the dressing reAlly cuts the sweet so it isn't sickening, unless you have sugar issues. thank you for this great recipe that mAkes a regular Joe like me look like a great cook!

text:
First time making and I followed the recipe and it turned out great with just a few minor changes  I added based on other reviews.  I agree with another reviewer stay away from cheap sauces.   I used a combination of  Jack Daniels and Famous Daves in mine.  Everyone loved it and have asked to have it again.  I cooked on low in the crock pot for 6 hours and then took out and shred the chicken (draining some of the liquid).  Then put it back in with more sauce for another 3 hours (both times on low).   Seasoned to taste with salt/pepper and some garlic (I would have added some onions but I have someone allergic to onions so didn't).  Saved some sauce for serving time (heated it up) for those that like a lot of sauce to add to their sandwich or plate serving.   Delicious and I have been asked to make it again for home as well as to bring to a neighborhood party.  Thank you for the recipe!

country:
None
text:
This is the best pulled chicken / pork recipe for a crock pot.
Turned out awesome!

Here a just a couple 'tweaks' I made:

-I'm with everyone who doesn't cook frozen meat in slow cooker; I had 6 small fresh chicken breasts which totaled about 2-3 lbs. 
-Cooked the chicken breasts in about 3/4 cup of organic chicken broth on low for 3 hours. Separated chicken from broth, threw out broth and then fork split and returned to crock pot. During prep of chicken breasts I added salt, pepper, garlic powder and Italian seasoning (roughly 1 tsp each) to broth / chicken.
-Once chicken was cooked and split I added about 14 oz of Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce, Drew's all natural Italian dressing,  3/4 cup brown sugar, wors. sauce  and set on low for about an hour. 
-Since the chicken was already cooked I then turned down to warm for remainder of day.

It's off the hook.....

I like sweet bbq, many don't, but you could use any smoked, mesquite, etc... sauce. Won't be bad - promise!

text:
I took the advice of other reviewers and used fresh thawed chicken breasts. I chose to cook on low, and two hours before completion I removed the breasts from the crockpot and shredded them, then return the meat to finish cooking while soaking up the flavor from the juices . After cooking was done  I strained the meat, returned the chicken to the crockpot, and added my desired amount of Sweet baby Ray's barbecue sauce. Closed the crockpot and let it warm up for a half an hour. We toasted buns in the oven and enjoyed this meal with a pan of cornbread. My family found it to be absolutely delicious and requested I save this recipe and make it again.

Extremely easy to make and the chicken stayed so moist! As someone who had never made "pulled" anything, I was stunned how the meat just fell off and I barely had to do anything! The only negative I'd say is that it isn't very "zesty," it's very sweet. That could be from the Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce I used, or from the brown sugar, but there was no zest to this at all. May try again with a spicier sauce. Otherwise, a great - and easy - dish! Put it on some rolls and the whole family loved it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good and easy. I agree with those who say the BBQ sauce you use makes a ton of difference. Use a top quality BBQ sauce, sweet or spicy, whichever you prefer. I used Famous Dave's. 
And to those who say "the sauce was burned and the chicken was all dried out," that is impossible if you keep the cover on for the entire cooking time, which is the cardinal rule of crockpot cooking. A little liquid to start in any crockpot recipe and the crockpot will make its own moisture while cooking and nothing will ever dry out, even on High. But I prefer cooking everything on Low. Just  KEEP THE COVER ON! (No peeking even)
That way for me in my crockpot, this recipe worked great at 6 hours on Low. Lots of moisture (needed to be drained at end), and very Tasty!

text:
I made this for dinner yesterday and my boyfriend and I enjoyed it a lot. I appreciate reviews from people that are only cooking for two, so I figured I would share my experience.

I halved the recipe(for 3 people just in case we wanted more) as I didn't need enough to feed 6 people. The alterations were fine. I did need to add a little more BBQ sauce than what the recipe called for, but that's it. I'm pretty sure the end product wouldn't have been tender enough otherwise. I used Baby Rays BBQ sauce and the chicken turned out delicious. 

I used frozen chicken and cooked everything on high for about 4 hours. That was perfect. A tip for anyone that wants an easier way of shredding chicken: Take out the chicken and use a mixer to shred it. I read that somewhere and have done it ever since. Such an easy and usually fast way to get shredded chicken!

I was worried that the sauce was too watery but once I shredded the chicken, it made the sauce thicken up a great deal.

You can definitely make alterations to fit your personal taste, but I think this recipe is spot on as is. All it needed was a little more sauce, but I don't really consider that altering the recipe.

Display Name:
Adijat Adelekan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3668130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for a potluck at work and it was a success! 
I made a few modifications to the recipe:

1. I used boneless skinless chicken thighs that I had on hand and trimmed as much excess fat as possible.
2. Because I wanted to ensure that the chicken would be fully cooked without potentially burning it if I left it to cook overnight to be ready in time for our early lunch the next day, I prepped the ingredients the night before----I seasoned the chicken thighs with Stubs barbecue rub and baked at 425F for about 40 minutes(or until fully cooked). Once the chicken was done, I drained off most of the liquid, shredded the meat (while removing any remaining excess fat) and placed it aside.
3. I finely sliced and caramelized one medium red onion and added it to the sauce recipe. I also added a dash of cayenne pepper and crushed red pepper flakes (to taste) for a touch of heat. I used Ken's Zesty Italian Dressing and Stubs Spicy barbecue sauce. I combined all of the sauce ingredients with the cooked shredded chicken and put it into the fridge overnight.
4. The next morning when I arrived at work,  I dumped the container of chicken/sauce into my slow cooker and let it cook on high for 2.5 hours and low for 1 hour so that it would be hot and ready to serve at lunch time-- It turned out extremely well and I would definitely make it again!

My overall recommendation would definitely be to use your favorite ingredients.

text:
I added about 1/2 cup of Bragg Raw Apple Cider Vinegar to give it a little healthy zing in addition to another cook's idea to add chicken broth, garlic, and pepper.  I'm not a huge fan of very sweet bbq sauces, and adding the broth and vinegar helped make it taste a little less sweet without sacrificing any flavor. It also didn't taste like someone just dumped a jar of sauce on shredded chicken.  I thickened this sauce after the chicken was cooked and shredded, and put the chicken back in it.  Everyone loved it! If I wasn't making this for kids, I think it would be amazing to give it a little kick by using a good quality spicy bbq sauce w/o HFCS. Kinder's or Trader Joe's Sriracha BBQ sauce are fantastic. I think they're organic, too, which is a plus.

text:
I didn't realize my italian dressing was expired, so I frantically looked for another solution and decided on the chicken broth. I added salt, pepper, and a touch of garlic powder per the user review. I think I might take out the garlic powder next time, but for 2 chicken breasts (6 was too much for my family), an 18 oz bottle and half a small can of chicken stock was sufficient. Its good! It wasn't great, but I think we will be making this again. Honestly, I don't see how italian dressing would add anything to this meal. As long as you are using the good BBQ sauce you shouldn't need anything  else.

country:
None
text:
This is a pretty decadent recipe, lots of sugar and lots of fat. It was a little too sweet for my taste, even with reducing the sugar to .2 cup. It seems strange to put salad dressing in a BBQ dish, but it makes a lot of sense. Chicken breasts are incredibly lean, but adding the dressing adds a bunch of fat, making this dish as succulent as pulled pork. I also added a few pinches of salt and crystal hot sauce to tame the sweetness a bit. Overall a delicious, if diet busting dish.

userID:
14496834
Display Name:
Kate Orr
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1575392.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night. It is delicious and I'm looking forward to having leftovers for lunch.

I took various recommendations from the reviews, including using liquid smoke. I did NOT have a problem with watery sauce and I only used 3 chicken breasts and kept all other portions equal to the original recipe.

I got home from the grocery and realized I had FORGOTTEN the Italian dressing. I had no dressing in the entire house, but I remembered that another reviewer had used a balsamic vinaigrette in replace of Italian, so what I did was grab a bottle of balsamic vinegar and a bottle of olive oil and splashed them in. (I didn't measure, but I eyeballed it to be about 2 tablespoons of each.)

Everyone seems to really enjoy the Famous Dave's Rich & Sassy BBQ, so that's what I used. I added about 2 cloves of minced garlic and some Montreal chicken seasoning. I cooked on high for 4 hours, shredded and let sit for another 20 minutes, and served on onion buns with red onion and sliced Claussen pickles. WONDERFUL!

Although I made a lot of changes, I really think the recipe would have been just great without. (I don't think I would make it without the liquid smoke, though.)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend and I LOVE this recipe! It's super easy to make for a small or large crowd. Definitely use 1/2 the amount of suggested chicken breasts (I used 3 instead of 6). An hour before turning the slow cooker off, shred the chicken. This will ensure that all the sauce will get soaked up- yum! And when reheating, make sure to put a moist towel over the chicken so it stays moist and the sauce does not burn.

My boyfriend likes eating this on a soft toasted roll will melted sharp cheddar cheese. I like it without the cheese.

Thank you Suzanne for the recipe!!!

Display Name:
Sara D.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2026035.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is restaurant quality BBQ and it was a big hit during the Super Bowl. Could not have had a better meal during the game. 

The only differences to the recipe I made were the following: I used thawed chicken, and I sauteed chopped onions (half an onion) before adding them to the crock pot, and I also added 4 cloves of pressed garlic to the sauce. I used Jack Daniel's Honey Smokehouse BBQ sauce. Cooked on low 4 hours,  then removed chicken to pull it, added it back and cooked on low for another hour. Added about 1 tablespoon of cornstarch to thicken, since sauce was slightly more watery than I liked - but it thickened up very nicely during the last hour.

Delicious and will definitely be making this recipe again in the future. It also could not have been easier.

text:
Edited to bump up a star. Have made 3 or 4 times now, most recently with boneless skinless thighs to pump up the flavor and that was the best this recipe has come out. I also think I had a larger sauce to meat ratio this time which kept it moist. I put it on while at work which means it sat for 10 hours on low (what can ya do) and it was basically boiling away when I got home and had some burnt bits but I scooped those out and it still tasted amazing. I was worried it was too liquidy but I stirred it up and shredded the chicken, turned it to warm and let it sit for 15-30 min and it was great! I use Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory Brown Sugar sauce and with the additional brown sugar in the recipe it's quite sweet so you could maybe reduce the brown sugar added.

text:
Making this for dinner tonight and it's actually still in the slow cooker. Absolutely delish!!!! I used fresh chicken breast not frozen and seasoned it with salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder and added a teaspoon of liquid smoke otherwise Followed the recipe exactly. I used Famous Dave's Rich & Sassy BBQ sauce and Kraft Tuscan House Italian Dressing. I cooked it on low for 6 hours and shredded the chicken just an hour before it was ready. It absorbed the sauce perfectly, I took a little bite to taste and can't wait until my husband gets home so I can have more!! Planning to eat it in a French roll kind of like the picture in the recipe with a small salad.

text:
I've made this recipe a hundred times over and it's always a hit!  So incredibly easy yet delicious!  I've switched from making this in the slow cooker to my instant pot. Now it's even faster, but just as delicious!  I add all ingredients into the instant pot and cook on non venting, high pressure for 25 minutes.  I let it naturally release for about 10 minutes and then open it up. Shred it right in the pot!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this!  Easy to make.  I gleaned from others' suggestions-- I cooked fresh, seasoned (whatever you like-- salt/ pepper/ garlic/ onion pwdr), chicken breasts on high or 2 1/2 hrs with chicken broth, threw in a chopped up onion.  Drained it, kept chicken & onions, shredded chicken, put back in slow cooker on high for an hour with homemade bbq sauce (rachel ray's smoky bbq sauce) and the other ingredients in this recipe.  

Served on buns with melted white cheddar & california slaw (from this site).

Yum!!

text:
I made this today and it turned out GREAT! I used 3 large, fresh chicken breast and cut each in half. I took the suggestions of several reviews and used a molasses based BBQ sauce, added 1 1/2 tsp of minced garlic, a tsp of liquid smoke, and seasoned the chicken with a little salt and pepper before adding the sauce. I cooked it on high for 3 hours, shredded the chicken, added it back to the pot and cooked for an additional hour on low. On a bun with a slice of cheddar, red onion, an pickles.... PERFECTION.

text:
I used this recipe as a "base" idea and made a few tweaks! I omitted the Italian dressing and added about 1/4 cup of Tapatio for some kick! I also added more Worcestershire sauce than the recipe calls for and threw in a diced onion and diced garlic. I cooked it for 4hrs on high, then shredded the chicken and cooked it on low for another hour and a half, stirring occasionally and removing the lid for the last half hour(because it wasn't thickening quick enough for me!). I served it on Texas toast with blue cheese crumbles and it was amazing!!

country:
None
text:
Great weeknight recipe with lots of leftover options! I cooked the frozen chicken breasts on low all day in 2C. chicken broth with pressed garlic & cracked pepper. I then skimmed off most of the fat & liquid at the 7th hour & shredded the chicken. I then added the sauce mixture I had reserved in the fridge & allowed chicken to cook on high for the final hour. I think the broth made the chicken tender & flavorful, the skimming of the fat & liquid made it less watery, the addition of the sauce in the final hour made it saucy & richer! The chicken made great quesadilla's the next night!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have three very picky teen-aged boys and all three LOVED this! I  used 2 1/2 lbs. of frozen chicken:  1 1/2 lbs of thighs and 1 1/2 lbs of breasts and one bottle of Jack Daniels Barbecue sauce.  I put everything in the crock-pot at lunchtime, then around 5:00 I shredded the chicken with a fork.  At that time, I added 1/2 cup Olive Garden Italian dressing, 4 Tbs Kroger brand Worcestershire sauce, 3/4 C dark brown sugar backed, and 3/4 cup of barbecue sauce (I used Kroger Thick & Spicy because I ran out of JD.) I could have let some of the liquid cook out of it, but chose instead to serve the BBQ open faced over buns/bread. The next time I make this I will probably drain the chicken and then add another whole bottle of BBQ sauce with the other ingredients.  Even though this means I will be draining off a lot of the sauce I added in the beginning, it will still have served as a marinade during the cooking.  I may also try a sauce that has a bit more of a kick as this was more sweet than "zesty".  I'll definitely make this again, and will probably even make it for a dish to take to work, a family event, etc.

I doubled this recipe, using defrosted chicken breasts.  Put a little less Worcestershire sauce in because it seemed a lot...cooked in the crockpot overnight on low, then shredded the meat.  The sauce was very watery, so I poured out a good amount of the liquid out and added a new mixture of bbq sauce, Worcestershire sauce, Italian dressing and brown sugar.  Put the sauce back in the crockpot with the shredded chicken and warmed it up, then served on hamburger buns with shredded lettuce and cheese slices.  Yum!!  Will definitely make again!

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-09-20T07:03:07.43
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1467064
Display Name:
Sue Ulintz Mosovich
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6584710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fantastic.  I had a party of 50+ people, used two crock pots divided evenly with this recipe -- one with a basic sweet bbq sauce and italian dressing, the other with a smoky chipotle bbq sauce and balsamic italian dressing (made with four seasons packets).  BOTH were fantastic - some of my guests were even convinced that the second recipe with the balsamic dressing was pork, not chicken.   I served this with hamburger buns, and everyone was thrilled.  Be aware that once the chicken is fully cooked, it looks a bit dry and the sauce is watery.  Don't be worried - as soon as you shred the chicken and return it to the pot, the chicken soaks up the sauce and it becomes just the right thickness.  In future, I plan to keep using the smoky sauce and balsamic dressing, but in general, you just can't go wrong with this recipe.

text:
I used fresh cleaned chicken breats, seasoned them with salt, pepper and garlic powder. The only change in ingredients was a 16oz bottle  instead of 12oz of bbq sauce, I used Weber Grill original. Cooked on high around three hours, shredded 4 of the breasts added back to the pot & stirred, threw the two breats on top and cooked low for maybe 1/2 hour. Very easy, I got one sandwich and my picky other half ate the rest over 3 days. The 2 remaining breasts I shredded & put in a sauce pan, added Franks Red Hot Buffalo Wing Sauce till warm. I liked this better than the bbq and he won't touch this.

text:
I love love love this recipe! The sauce is really good (I used Sweet Baby Ray's original), although I use 1/4 cup Italian dressing now (just my preference, it was still good with the full amount the recipe called for!). I did take some advice from reviewers, and used 3 fresh chicken breasts (a few times I've gotten chicken from the store right before making this, and they were partially frozen, and they still came out fine in the same time as fresh breasts). The reason I only used 3 is because I'm in college and I generally only cook for just myself, sometimes my boyfriend and friends. I cook them on 3 hours on high, and then shred the chicken and mixed the shredded chicken with the sauce well, then cook for another hour on low. I thought the sauce amount was perfect for 3 large breasts, I didn't have too much or too little for my personal tastes. Thank you so much for sharing your recipe :)

text:
I also read that it's risky to slow cook frozen meats, so I used thawed bone in chicken thighs and set the temp low and for 3.5hrs (I dislike overcooked meat).  As with other reviewers, I felt the sauce was too liquid-ey (though after shredding, the meat did absorb a lot of it), so I doctored it up with some flour.  I used a good quality honey bbq sauce and added onions on the bottom before covering with chicken.  The sauce came out perhaps too sweet b/c of this.  I'm not as impressed as other ppl seem to be and will not be repeating this recipe.

Update:  Followed directions and used frozen bone in leg quarters.  Used bottled sauces that were available in the fridge.  Barely even measured.  Family really liked it this time.  The meat only took 3 hrs to cook.  Still a touch too liquidy.  Will make again if I want to use up dressings and sauces.

text:
Absolutely fabulous!  Due to schedule, I cooked it the night before on high for about 4 hours. Shredded the meat and let it sit all night in the sauce in the fridge. Heated it up the next day to eat it--so delicious! I used fresh chicken breast as did not have frozen. I used Meijer Carolina BBQ sauce. Also, I had no italian dressing, I subbed 1/4 c of Newmans Own Oil and Vinegar dressing instead of the 1/2 c italian dressing; still added brown sugar and worcestershire sauce as called for in recipe.  My husband told me to give it a ten before he realized the rating system only goes up to 5 stars! :)
We ate it on sub rolls with coleslaw on top. Thank you for an amazing BBQ!!
P.S. I love garlic, but this recipe DOES NOT NEED it!~

This recipe was delicious and so easy. We all enjoyed it very much with a few changes as some reviewers suggested. Defrosted chicken breast before placing in crock pot, 1/2 chopped onion, 3 minced garlic cloves. text:
This was such a good recipe. It was the best item at a potluck picnic this summer. Everyone loved it. I purchased all the ingredients at a Canadian Superstore. I used Splenda brown sugar instead of raw brown sugar because the Cattle Boys BBQ sauce already had enough sugar in it. I chose the PC Blue Menu Italian dressing. Instead of using buns, I used PC Blue Menu Naan bread heated with a little olive oil on the stove. Warning: if you shred your chicken super fine, it ends up absorbing away most of the sauce.

text:
I doubled this recipe as I was cooking for a larger group. Because of this, my cooking times were longer than those outlined here. I used fresh chicken instead of frozen, just because I like to make sure I clean my chicken first, and because so many reviewers mentioned that it turned out watery. I also omitted the brown sugar because I was using honey BBQ sauce and was afraid it would be too sweet. This was a total hit with my guests and I will definitely be making it again! The leftovers will be great on BBQ chicken pizza too!

text:
I made this last week and omg, the entire family LOVED it. So much so that there wasn't even any left over afterwards! My wife who doesn't really like chicken said it was the best 'homemade' bbq she's ever had, my daughter said it's her favorite thing with chicken.

I used a bbq sauce (12 bones, a local bbq place) that had molasses and i didn't have any problem with it being too runny or the other problems some have had. I cooked it for 7 hours, shredded the chicken at the 6th hour and the shredded chicken just sucked all the sauce right up.  

Seriously, this is so good I joined just to leave this review

I followed the recipe exactly, except for the Worcestershire sauce since I didn't have any on hand. I cooked it on low for 5 hours, shred the chicken, and then cooked it for another hour. It was really moist and the flavor was great. However, it tasted pretty much the same to me as my normal crock pot BBQ chicken, which is made without the Italian dressing. Others said that using frozen chicken breasts resulted in a watery sauce, but mine came out fine.

text:
This recipe is a keeper for sure! The chicken came out so tender and full of flavor. I did thaw my chicken breasts and patted dry because reading other reviews i didnt want my sauce to get watered down. Also added a small chopped onion and some liquid smoke with famous daves sweet and tangy and a little famous daves devil spit (be careful with the devils spit becasue it has a bite!). Cooked on low for 5 hours and then pulled and shredded the chicken and added back for another two hours. Used garlic butter on some buns and toasted, added coleslaw on top of the meat to complete the sandwich. It was the perfect somertime treat with some baked beans and chips. Thank you for the simple and tasty addition to my recipe box

None
text:
The best pulled "pork" recipe ever!

I used Bull's Eye B-B-Q Sauce (Texas style), added a medium chopped onion and 6 large chopped garlic cloves and didn't alter the recipe in any other way, except my THREE very large breasts were fresh and not frozen.

I shredded the chicken after two hours on high heat and, in less than an additional hour, this dish was finished.  I served it open-style on potato rolls along with cole slaw and a mixed-leaf green salad.  Delicious and healthy!

My husband LOVED this spicy treat but I had a hard time convincing him that the meat was chicken and not pork!

Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe!

Excellent and so easy! I cooked 4 frozen chicken breasts in low-sodium chicken broth, sliced onion and garlic on high for 3 hours and drained it. Then I shredded the chicken, returned it to the crockpot and put the barbeque sauce/italian dressing mixture in and cooked it on low for another 5 hours. It was very tasty! This is a keeper!

text:
I used 7 frozen chicken breasts and cooked overnight for a potluck the next day.  I did not add the brown sugar because I used Baby Ray's Brown Sugar and Hickory BBQ sauce.  I only put in 1 T of Worcestershire sauce and of course 1/2 c. dressing.  When I woke in the morning it smelled great in the house.  Chicken was very easy to shred.  There was plenty of "juice" and I let it soak it up till serving time.  The group at the party really liked it.  Nice and easy, and very tasty.  Think I will try this out as a regular in my menu rotation.
Update- 7/20/17 still a winner. Made with three fresh not frozen chicken breasts. Cooked on low 5 hours. Took chicken out with slotted spoon and he's a TIP-  put chicken in stand mixer to shred. You'll never shred with forks again. So easy. Put shredded chicken back in on warm for one hour. Awesome!

text:
I used a barbecue sauce that isn't my favorite, but this recipe was still good. I had two HUGE frozen boneless skinless chicken breasts and made the regular amount of sauce. While they were cooking there was barely enough sauce to cover the breasts, so I don't know how I was going to be able to fit 6 in there. If they were smaller and thawed you could possibly jam them in there. Maybe the author of the recipe can add another measurement such as lbs, oz, ect. so that we have a better idea of the volume that's needed. But this was ok for me to have extra sauce cause I like my BBQ pretty sloppy. :)

text:
Pretty good recipe.  I halved the recipe and used a couple of bone-in chicken breasts.  I added half a chopped-up onion to the recipe as well.  When I pulled out the chicken to shred it, I added a couple of tablespoons of flour to the liquid to help thicken it.  The end result was pretty good.  I think the only thing I'll change will be not adding the brown sugar next time since it was a little too sweet.  I used Jack Daniels BBQ sauce, which is a little sweet so that's probably the reason it was a little sweeter than I'd like.

Wow. Super awesome!  I read all of the reviews and still went with the frozen chicken.  The only changes I made.. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delish!  This recipe was great!  I added onion and fresh garlic to the sauce also, and like others, I used fresh chicken and cooked it on low for five hours.  I would recommend cooking it less, mine was a tad dry (until I added more of the sauce mix, which I reserved some of and added during the last hour).  I would recommend cooking for three hours then shred the chicken, and add the reserve sauce with about an hour left.  Mine was also a little watery so I also added about a fourth of a cup of flour to thicken it up before I shredded the chicken.  It turned out so goooooddddd!  My boyfriend and I literally used our fingers to clean our plates.  I will definately be making this again!

userID:
4254298
Display Name:
Wendy Stout
isPro:

38

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1831726.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  Based on other reviews, I defrosted my chicken first and threw it in the slow cooker with two cups of chicken stock.  I made the sauce in a bowl - no alterations (I used Sweet Baby Ray's Original and Wishbone Light Italian dressing).  When the chicken was done, I drained it, shredded it, and added it to the sauce.  I kept it warm on the stovetop til I was ready to serve it, but you could put it back in the slow cooker.  I served it on hot dog buns with extra sharp Cracker Barrel cheese and we all liked it a lot.
Review:

text:
Fantastic!  Entire family loved it.  Used about 5 semi-defrosted breasts, KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce and store brand Italian dressing.  Plenty sweet so could have left out the sugar, but it was fine w/ it.  Added 1/2 chopped onion.  I cooked on high 3 1/2 hours, shredded the chicken and then let it cook another 30 minutes.  Served on hoagie buns.  So yum!

Rating:

helpfulCount:

userID:
8238859
Display Name:
lovetocook
isPro:

followersCount:
0

2

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this chicken dish!  I also took the advice of others by shredding the chicken in the sauce.  I used 2 large chicken breasts and one thigh/leg quarter all skinless.  I season my chicken first then freeze it using freezer bags until ready to use.  The chicken was completely thawed before I placed it in the crock pot.  When it was about 90% done, I drained the oil, added the sauce to the crock pot, then added the shredded chicken. I cooked it for about an hour longer.  For my sauce:  I also used Sweet Baby Ray's Honey barbecue sauce based on the advice from another user.  The sauce had a great consistency once done.  Here are some things I did differently:  I didn't have Worcestershire sauce so instead I used a little soy sauce and more of the Teriyaki sauce.  I also used Bruschetta Italian dressing by Wishbone (delicious!!)  I omitted the sugar since Teriyaki is already sweet. I also chopped an onion and some fresh garlic and cooked it with the sauce in the last hour.  I served on top of a baked potato with shredded sharp cheddar.  A delicious dish!!

Really can't recommend this enough.

text:
Awesome recipe!  We made this for a family gathering and everyone raved over it.  We used Sweet Baby Ray's Honey BBQ sauce and store brand Italian Dressing.  It was the perfect ratio of sweet to zesty.  The only thing we added was a teaspoon of Liquid Smoke, as suggested by previous posters.  Don't panic if the sauce looks a little thin towards the end--once you shred the chicken and stir it back in, it'll thicken up in no time with the lid off.  Otherwise, stir in a little flour.  Definitely a keeper! Thanks!

text:
So easy and sooooo freaking good.  I never use frozen chicken and I cook it on high for about 4 hours and it perfectly juicy and flavorful.  I do pull it all apart about 4 hours and let it sit and cook on low for another 30 min or so. And I forgot to add that I use a little liquid smoke as well- adds to the flavor- but dont use much!

text:
This was absolutely delicious and so easy.  I cooked on high for four hours until the chicken was "shred tender."  Removed and shredded chicken, added chicken back into the crock pot with the barbecue sauce, and heated for another 30 minutes.  Once I shredded the chicken, the sauce wasn't a bit watery.  Everyone raved about it, and it was even better reheated the next day.  A keeper :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly (using Stubb's smokey mesquite barbecue sauce and Girard's Venice Italian dressing) and thought it turned out pretty darn good.  The chicken was extremely moist and tender, but there were a few things I'd like to improve.   The dish was very wet and saucy even after having cooked for the last hour on high with the crock pot lid off (to cook off some liquid)- I'll have to experiment with cooking time or using thawed chicken to see if that makes the sauce thicker.  The other issue was that my boyfriend thought the chicken was too sweet- I can't stand super-sweet barbecue sauce and I was okay with the amount of sweetness, but I will likely reduce the sugar next time to get a more complex taste.  I served this on broiled kaiser buns with cole slaw and French's onion crisps- I was trying to recreate a local restaurant's chicken sandwich and it was a pretty close approximation!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!! I made this for my fiance and I, and he took it to work for lunch the next day and several people asked for the recipe.  I did change/add a few thing:

- I used 3 fresh chicken breasts (as others suggested)... before adding them to the crock pot, I poked holes in them and seasoned them with salt, pepper, and 6 cloves of chopped fresh garlic (we love garlic!)
- I used Jack Daniels BBQ sauce (as others suggested)
- I omitted the Worcestershire sauce (didn't have any - it doesn't need it)
- I added 1/2 cup chopped green onion
- I also added 1/2 cup chicken broth

I serve mine on a chiabata bun or a hawaiian bread roll.  If you find your sauce too watery, add a starch slurry (mix one tablespoons water to one tablespoon corn starch in a small bowl, then add to mixture)

None
text:
GREAT recipe! Super easy and awesome.
Few tips:
1. EVERYTHING depends on the BBQ sauce you use. We used the trader joes Kentucky gold and it was awesome (and the TJ balsamic italian dressing).
2. You don't need the sugar! I skipped it completely and we didn't miss a thing.
3. dark..light...doesn't matter what meat you use - it all tastes the same.  Save yourself some calories and stick with white.
4. I used frozen breasts and it was perfect.
5. I threw in some onions and they were a total hit.

text:
Yummy! This turned out so delicious. I added some chopped onion, about 1/2 of a large onion. I mixed it in with the sauce before pouring over the chicken. I cooked it on high for about 3 1/2 hours. Then, I took out the chicken and shredded it. I strained the sauce into a pan and cooked it down some on the stove to thicken it a bit. Then I poured it over the shredded chicken. I served it on whole wheat hamburger buns with slices of colby jack cheese. My kids loved it!! Even the pickiest one. It was so easy and I was able to make it quickly with what I had on hand. I will definitely be making this again! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This came out so tender and delicious.  I only had about 1/3 of a bottle of barbeque sauce so I whisked it together with a mixture of apple cider vinegar, brown sugar, ketchup, balsamic vinaigrette dressing, salt, garlic powder and chili powder.  I used a little more Worcestershire sauce than the recipe calls for and also put in a diced onion, diced green pepper, and a diced tomato with the chicken.  I cooked in in a crockpot for about 6 hours on low and it came out great.  After shredding the chicken and adding some sauce to keep it moist, I would suggest keeping the extra sauce on the side so people can add the amount they prefer on their sandwiches.  I served my chicken on wheat sandwich buns with pickles, alfalfa sprouts and cheddar cheese.  I'll definitely use this recipe again.

text:
Love this recipe! Very versatile and forgiving. I have made this several times and it always turns out great! I use frozen chicken (which is fine as long as you let it cook all the way) I use whatever marinades, sauces, etc. I happen to have on hand and usually add some extra peppers and onions. I put the slow cooker on high and forget about it. After about 4 hour I shred the chicken and then let it cook for about another hour. Serve over potatoes, or on a sandwich, or tortillas, whatever you like.

Display Name:
Debbie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My grocery store had a great sale on bone-in breasts, so I used those.  I have a 5-Qt cooker, so I had to layer the chicken.  After 3 hours on high, the top layer was not cooked, so I put the top layer on the bottom and the bottom layer on top.  I cooked for 2 more hours on high.  I removed the chicken and shredded it, setting it aside.  I strained the liquid in case there were any bones and set the sauce aside.  I put the chicken back in the cooker, put in the sauce, stirred a couple of times and cooked another hour.    
     I did not add the brown sugar.  I added 2 Tblsp. of soy sauce and used Sweet Baby Ray's Regular BBQ Sauce.  I also added the diced onions that others have suggested.
     EVERYONE loved it!

Just made this and it was sooo delicious and easy.  I only used 3 chicken breasts.  Threw them in the crockpot fully frozen.  Made the sauce exactly as instructed and poured over the frozen chicken. It was sooo good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Family loved it (2 teens + parents).  I used 2 bone in chicken breasts and 2 bone in thighs, added 1.5 c chicken stock, cooked on #2 for 3 hours, then on #1 for 2 hours (while gone). Drained liquid, deboned and shredded.  Added bbq sauce, italian dressing and worc. sauce to crock pot while shredding, added chicken and sliced red onion, cooked on #3 for 30-40 minutes while prepping the rest of the meal. Served on buns, tops brushed with oil, dash of garlic salt and broiled for 1.5 min.  We tried 3 different cheeses - provolone, cheddar and swiss.  I preferred provolone.  Great meal served with salad, carrot sticks, celery sticks, and sliced peaches.

text:
This was absolutely delicious. I used frozen chicken thighs, 18 oz bottle of Kraft Honey Roasted Garlic barbeque sauce, 1/2 c italian salad dressing, no brown sugar (didn't have any), 2 Tbs Worc. Sauce, ! Tbs Liquid smoke 1/2 large vidalia onion, 4 whole cloves of garlic after reading several reviews and based on personal preferences. I cooked the chicken on high for 3 hours then deboned and shredded the chicken then cooked on low for 1 hour. I served it over a baked potato with cheddar cheese, sour cream, and chives for myself. My hubby preferred his on a sandwich. My picky 17 year old daughter said "this tastes really good mom, better than that restaurant we go to."  Thank you for a terrific family recipe!

Family loves this! Super easy and super delicious! And there are so many things you can do with it. I use the leftovers on a green salad, or on a tortilla as a mini taco. My 3 year old granddaughter just eats the chicken with a fork along with the rest of her meal. It is so versatile that it can be individually adjusted to fit everyone's taste buds. I basically prepare it according to recipe, but last night I was out of Italian dressing, so just used vege oil with some Italian seasoning, and it was fine. This is a staple dish in our household.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as the recipe directed. Instead of store bought salad dressing, I made a very tasty Basic Italian Salad Dressing found on Epicurious.
I stopped cooking the chicken after I measured the internal chicken temperature at 180F - this was almost 6 hours on low.
On sampling the food, the sauce was very acidic. This might have something to do with the BBQ sauce having vinegar in it and then adding a salad dressing, which even store bought dressing has vinegar in it. That is lots of acidity in my opinion!
The chicken had formed a crispiness on the exterior. Internally it was pull-apart easy (kind of like pulled pork), however, I found the chicken dry.
Perhaps cooking the chicken from frozen had something to do with this.
All in all, this is something I will not be making again.

text:
I read the reviews from those others who found the chicken got mushy or dry or that there was no taste to the actual chicken. I used frozen chicken since I was going to be at work all day. I also added water to help retain the moisture. I seasoned the chicken and also added red onions and other spices. After cooking in the bbq mix for 8 hours, the chicken was still dry and a bit mushy and no real seasoning to it after soaking in bbq sauce. I think that this may be good to cook on high for 2 hours in your crockpot but not for more than that. It was good to try something new, but I won't be trying this again.

I used Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce.

4 lbs FRESH chicken breast (6 med-lg) 2 t liquid smoke, 1 t cayenne, 4 minced garlic cloves, 1 sliced white onion, 1 cup newmans italian, about 24 oz sweet baby rays bbq, (because i had SOO much chicken) and i cut the amount of BBQ sauce in half for the first 3 hours i cooked on high, then i shredded the chicken then added the last half of bbq sauce for another hour on high. served on hamburger buns with corn on the cob and garlic mashed potatoes. yum!! probably over 3 days worth of leftovers too.

text:
excellent! I have made this with frozen and fresh chicken, both were great. For those who thinks this turns out runny,I  followed the tips on shredding the chicken and let it cook for a little while longer. MADE A HUGE DIFFERENCE! it really soaks up the extra liquid. in fact if the next time I make 6 ckn breasts i will add extra sauce because it soaked so much of it up. i also followed a tip about putting butter and garlic powder on the rolls then broiling them, the mix of the garlic and barbeque sauce was wonderful.

text:
2/11 i used 3 frozen and followed the reviewer who said slow cook on high 4 hours in chicken broth, drain, shred and add ing. and low for 2 hours.  since i used only 3 breasts, i halved the ing. and it was not enough.  VEry tasty though. make again except use all the sauce.  i used chibatta rolls and it was too doughy. try other ones next time.
1/2014: used 4 breasts, defrosted first, followed recipe exactly and way too much sauce.  high for 3 hours, shred and then back in for 1 hr on low. very good, make again. 1/16: package of thighs, and slow for 6 hours, awesome. great on soft rolls with poppy seeds and a side of cole slaw from this site.

text:
This turned out great and was very simple to make. I used fresh chicken thighs but didn't have the Italian Dressing so I used the Italian Dressing dry mix instead and sprinkled it over the chicken.  Then mixed Sweet Baby Rays BBQ Sauce with the brown sugar, Worchestire Sauce and 1 tsp of Liquid Smoke.  Cooked on high for 3 hrs, removed chicken, shredded it and removed the bones and put the shredded chicken back in the crockpot.  Added garlic powder to the mix and set on low for another hr and voila!  So delish, will definitely make it again.

text:
This was so delicious and SO easy.  I only used 3 chicken breasts, and followed one of the suggestions below saying to keep all other measurements the same.  I shredded the chicken about 15 mins before eating it, and put it back in to absorb the sauce.  If I;m home earlier next time i might shred a few hrs before eating.  Also, did not eat this as a sandwich, just ate the chicken with some other side dishes.  To be honest, I couldnt really taste the addition of the italian dressing, but I guess it just thinned out the bbq sauce a little.  I also used a light italian instead of regular.  I will definitely make this again- I have the leftovers for lunch today!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We liked this recipe better with skinless, bone-in chicken thighs.  My wife does not like dark meat except in this recipe.  We used 4 oz of Sweet Baby's Ray's BBQ Sauce, 4 ounces of white wine (Oak Leaf pinot grigio from Wal-Mart works fine), 4 oz of Newman's Own Olive Oil & Vinegar dressing, 8 oz. of tomato sauce, two tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce and we omitted the brown sugar.  We cook one hour on high, then reduce the setting to low for four hours or until the meat is falling off the bone.  We serve over rice.  Leftovers make a nice lunch.

text:
Not impressed with this, at all.  Honestly, I think the frozen chicken breasts are where it all goes wrong.  As they thaw I think they release too many juices that water down the bbq in both flavor and consistency.  I used a good, molasses-based bbq sauce (Famous Dave's Rich and Sassy) and you could barely taste it.  There wasn't even any color to the bbq.  I had to add a ton more for there to be any flavor at all...more than double.  Although so much easier, next time I will definitely not use frozen breasts.

text:
I love to cook, but I love easy days when I can throw something in my slow cooker. I followed the recipe at first, but after 3 1/2 hours on high, I took the chicken out, shredded it up, seasoned it with garlic powder, pepper, and a dash of paprika. I put it back in the sauce in the crock pot and added some extra barbecue sauce that I had. It turned out great! It was served with corn on the cob and mashed potatoes. Tomorrow's lunch will be the "barbecue chicken" on buns. Yum! :)

text:
I used the suggestions from Cooking 101.  I took three boneless chicken breasts and rubbed garlic powder, salt and pepper on them.  I placed them in the crock-pot for about 5-6 hrs on low.  I shredded the chicken and drained the grease.  I then added the BBQ sauce mixture and added it to the chicken and cooked another 1-2 hours on low.  I used Jack Daniels bbq sause w/ brown sugar.  I used the meat as a topping on my loaded baked potatos, and they were wonderful.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-08-18T13:01:51.03
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
5225832
Display Name:
goodcook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love to cook esp with a slow cooker and the slow cooker chicken recipe I have is good but needed some umph :) So when I saw that italian dressing was an ingredient I thought..it might be what I was looking for.  So I put in 4 chicken breasts in the slow cooker BUT I poured in 4-5 cups boiling water, 3 chicken bouillon cubes, 2 clove minced garlic and seasoned the chicken with garlic pepper salt and a chicken seasoning. (no bbq sauce) Cooked it on low for 3 hrs.  I drained the chicken juices and fat into a separate bowl (will explain why later) and shredded the chicken and THEN added the recommended sauce along with 2 TBS petite diced onion, 2 minced garlic cloves and 1 TBS cornstarch (I tasted the chicken before I added it back to the empty crock pot and it tasted good :)  I let it cook on low for 2 hrs and then turned it off. THIS was amazing!  We all enjoyed it thoroughly! I decided that I didn't want to use 2 bottles of our Head County BBQ sauce (local restaurant) so that's why I decided to cook as I did PLUS (and now I'll explain why I reserved the juices) the remaining juices I poured over my dog's food so he could enjoy it too. If I disposed of the fat and bbq sauce as most recommended and then add again, I would've wasted sauce and my dog would've been sad lol  I gave it 4 stars bc you really need to drain the sauce. But I think mine gets 5! Also the BBQ sauce we use is sweet and we like a little kick with our so I used ZESTY italian dressing and it was wonderful!

text:
This is a HIT!!  When I took the chicken out to shred it, I also removed some of the sauce because it seems like a lot. Before I added the chicken back in, I disolved 1 TBSP cornstarch in water and then stirred into sauce left in crockpot to thicken.  I put the chicken back in and added enough of the sauce I removed to make it juicy but not overly so.

userID:
4886037
Display Name:
pokey
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had 6 fresh chicken breasts I needed to do something with and found this recipe - never thought to use my slow cooker. What a great idea!  I didn't have Italian dressing so I just used 2 kinds of barbeque sauce - one honey/garlic and the other had a smoky flavor.  Layered the breasts in the slow cooker and poured the sauce over. Also added about half an onion finely chopped and the brown sugar.  It was fabulous!!  I noticed the onion disentegrated and melded into the chicken  during cooking, so next time I think I'll also finely chop some red pepper with it.  Used the cooking time of the recipe and the chicken fell apart by moving it around with a fork - I didn't need to pull it.  VERY tender.  I did find that it needed a little kick so next time I'll make sure to have the italian dressing and maybe use a little hot sauce.  Used it on buns like the photo in the recipe, then used the left overs several ways....with grilled veggies in wraps, in fried rice, and made a sandwich for my daughter's lunch.  Love the versatility of this recipe - I'm going to always have some made up on hand in the freezer.

text:
Really good, and I'm not usually wild about bbq.  I put two frozen breasts in with about half a beer, slow cooked on low for about 5 hours, drained the beer out, shredded the chicken and added the other ingredients, but left out the sugar.  Also threw in some garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper.  Two chicken breasts (about one lb of chicken total) made three big sandwiches for us and a lot of extra nibbles out of the crock pot.
Edited 5/27: Here we are four days later, and my boyfriend is already asking me to make this again. It's that good!

text:
I made this tonight and the husband LOVED it.  It's so good and such a simple recipe that uses ingredients I always have on hand. I used Kraft Hickory Smoked BBQ sauce and since it's a sweeter sauce anyway, only put 2 tbsp of brown sugar in.  I used 3 thawed chicken breasts and cooked it on High for 3 1/2 hours.  I ended up using a whole 18 oz. bottle of BBQ sauce, but that was because I knew that it was going to end up sitting on warm for awhile (my husband ended up having to work late last minute). This is a keeper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Seeing reviews which state this recipe is dry leads me to believe that folks don't know their crockpots. If your crockpot doesn't have a probe, it really is worth your time to use a meat thermometer and determine how long it takes for meat to fully cook in your crockpot. You might be surprised.  I used Cooking101's revisions but used four (4) full breasts on the bone; thawed NEVER FROZEN. For this quantity of meat I used an entire 28 oz. bottle of Jack Daniel's Original No. 7, 1/2 C Newman's Own Family Recipe Italian, and 1/2 C brown sugar. Next time I will use a zestier Italian dressing, as the NOFR added nothing to the dish (which is why I increased the BBQ sauce).  I served on browned Honey Wheat Kaiser rolls with sauteed green beans and sweet potato fries. All the kids, ages 3 - 11 ate it without complaint.

text:
This was sooooo good!  I made it according to the recipe except I used 4 chicken breasts (because that was all I had) instead of 6 and it turned out great.  The sauce is watery when you first take the cooked chicken out of the crockpot, but I found once you shred the chicken and add it back to the sauce the meat absorbs the liquid very quickly.  The end result is not watery at all and tastes better than any restaurant barbecued chicken I've ever had!

text:
We made this using Kraft Hickory Smoked BBQ sauce, and Kraft Tuscan House Italian salad dressing. It turned out AMAZING! We added about 1/2 cup more salad dressing than requested, and 1/3 cup chicken broth. 30 min before serving, we pulled the chicken breasts out and shredded them, then placed the chicken back in the slow cooker for the remaining 30 min. To serve we placed the shredded chicken in ciabatta bread, and used the remaining sauce for dipping. Will be made again real soon!

It was good, but there was too much sauce.  I did have to thicken it at the end of cooking.  I used a whole chicken (not cut up), and just put the whole chicken in the slow cooker and poured the sauce over it.  At the end of the cooking time, I just pulled the bones out. I used Carolina Classic barbecue sauce, and served it with mashed potatoes, but it would also be good on rolls, or over baked potatoes.  I didn't see that the Italian dressing and sugar added much to the flavor, and I'll probably leave them out next time, and just use half the bottle of barbecue sauce while it's cooking.  I can always add the rest of the bottle when it's finished cooking, if it needs more.

1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: I REALLY WANTED TO GIVE THIS A SECOND TRY (WHO DOESN'T LIKE BBQ CHICKEN???). THE TRICK IS TO FOLLOW ZANE'S RECIPE EXACTLY AND COOK NO LONGER THAN 4 HOURS ON HIGH (OR THE EQUIVALENT AMOUNT OF TIME ON LOW). IT IS CRITICAL THAT YOU DON'T OVERCOOK YOUR CHICKEN (DRY CHICKEN = YUCK!). I HAVE ALSO NOTICED THAT THE TEXTURE OF FROZEN (COOKED) MEAT IS NEVER AS GOOD AS FRESH, BUT THAT'S JUST MY OPINION. :) MY FINAL OBSERVATION IS THAT THE ADDITIONAL INGREDIENTS ADDED TO A GOOD QUALITY BBQ SAUCE MAKE NO DIFFERENCE (I COULD BARELY DETECT THEM). IF YOU HAVE THEM HANDY, ADD THEM. IF NOT, SKIP THE "EXTRAS" AND JUST ADD A LITTLE MORE BBQ SAUCE TO COMPENSATE. THIS IS NOW WORTHY OF A REPEAT PERFORMANCE. This was allright. I guess I just don't care for slow cooked chicken because it ALWAYS turns out dry - and this time was no exception (my chicken was so dry, it literally crumbled). :( Having said this, I did make a few changes. As Cooking 101 did, I too cooked my seasoned chicken in broth FIRST (6 hours on low setting). When my fiance and I returned from the zoo, I removed and shredded my chicken, drained the broth, mixed with the sauce ingredients (FYI, I used Famous Dave's rich & sassy BBQ sauce) and cooked another 2 hours. I served our BBQ "spuds-style" as Zane suggested with fresh corn on the cobb, baked beans & garlic bread on the side. Thanks for sharing, Zane :)

text:
WOW!  I made this for the second time today.  The first time it was just me and my husband and we had leftovers for three days...that was too much, ha ha, even though it was delicous!  (I served it on baked potato, then red rice, then soft rolls.  Preferred the rolls.  I'm feeding three men and three women tonight, including myself and there will be plenty to go around.  Serving over rice and mixed veggies, with biscuits on the side, to ensure the diners can sop up that incredible sauce!  I added half a chopped onion about an hour before the chicken was done cooking.  I 'pulled' it about two hours before it was done.  I cooked it for eight hours total.  Don't worry, the sauce thickens!  I used Kraft Hickory BBQ Sauce, an entire bottle and added a very generous amount of fresh ground pepper (a must in almost everything I cook).  My Mom, who is VERY picky about what she eats (and who cooks it, ha ha), got to sample this dish a few moments ago and she LOVED it.  Absolutely loved it.  All she could say at first was "mmmmmmmmm" and she asked for another sample, ha ha.  She said it's flavourful and the perfect balance of sweet and BBQ-y.  My Mom's approval?  Priceless.  It must be good.

text:
My family and I thought this was really good. I went 4 stars instead of 5 b/c we weren't BOWLED OVER but it's definitely quite good. The first time I made it, we had it on buns. Second time, on Boboli with mozzarella as BBQ chicken pizza. We liked the pizza best. I made it according to the recipe (with Sweet Baby Rays Honey Sauce). I read reviews mentioning dry chicken and a sauce that was thin. I found that once you shred the chicken and return to the pot, the sauce is perfect. And the recipe calls for frozen chicken so if you opt to thaw yours first, take that into consideration on cook time to avoid drying out. Shredding into the sauce helps that as well.

text:
Very good and easy recipe. The only changes I made were putting a sliced onion in the bottom of the crock pot and using about 10 oz Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce as that is all I had. I used frozen split chicken breasts (bone in) with the skin removed. About an hour before dinner I took the chicken off the bone (it just fell off) and shredded it then let it sit in the crock pot for the remaining hour - sauce really thickened up once chicken was shredded. Great on rolls. Nice flavor. Very versatile recipe - could be used with pork or beef. Will definately make again.

text:
I made this yesterday. The chicken turnd out very tender & had good flavor. Like others, the sauce was way to thin. After chicken was cooked, I took the chicken out & placed in a dish & then put the sauce in a pan & added corn starch to thicken. I did not like the way it tasted at all. What I did was mix up some more sauce like you make to pour over chicken in crock pot. I heated on the stove & poured over chicken breast. Shredded up the left over chicken for sandwiches. I think the frozen chicken waters down the sauce as it cooks, & it just doesn't taste near as good as it does when freshly made. After making the fresh sauce, it was yummy.

I made this to take to a Halloween party. I took another reviewers suggestions and slow cooked the chicken breast in chicken broth with seasonings for 4 hours (on high for 2 hours and low for 2 hours), drained, shredded the chicken and added the remaining ingredients and returned to slow cooker on low for another 2 hours. Everyone at the party really enjoyed this dish. I think next time I will try making with chicken thighs as I noticed the breast seemed a bit dry. Thank you for sharing your recipe!

text:
This is pretty good shredded for sandwiches but make sure you use a good bbq sauce. It will make a difference. Also, I just have to add that experts recommend you do not put frozen foods in the crockpot. All foods should be defrosted before cooking so the food temperature can reach 140 degrees as soon as possible otherwise it can sit too long at an unsafe temperature. I thawed the chicken before placing in my slow cooker. My kids loved this!

text:
Excellent! It rivals pulled pork for my favorite type of saucy hot sandwich. I used 3 thawed chicken breasts, 3/4 cup of BBQ sauce (I used Bullseye), 1/4 cup Italian dressing, around 2 TBS of brown sugar, and around 1 TBS Worcestershire sauce. Oh, and I added a can of mushrooms to the sauce. It was excellent. :) Maybe 20 minutes before serving, I added a couple more tablespoons of BBQ sauce to make it a little saucier. I followed Cooking 101's suggestion of seasoning, cooking, and draining the chicken (and 'shrooms!) before adding the sauce and it worked fabulously. Thanks for sharing, Zanne!

This is an excellent recipe. I was looking for a recipe that didn't use "cream of xxx soup". Yum, yum, yum! I used Sweet Baby Ray's brand BBQ sauce...also I only had 5 chicken breasts & it was fine (cooked on low for 6 hours). Since I added the onion towards the end, it softened up - but not too much, it still had a nice crunch.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe, but my boyfriend enjoyed it more than I did.  I followed several reviewers' advice and cooked the chicken (frozen) in a spice and chicken broth mixture on low for six hours.  I then removed and shred the chicken, drained the fat and liquid, and added my sauce mixture.  Because I used a honey barbecue sauce, I didn't add any brown sugar because I thought it would be too sweet.  The chicken cooked too long, however, and turned into mush after an additional hour with the sauce.  Next time I'll reduce the cooking time drastically.  Other than that, a very good recipe and one that I will try with modifications again.  Served on low fat, wheat buns with corn on the cob on the side.

text:
I have made this twice.  The first time I shredded the chicken and served as sandwiches.  The next time I served whole with rice and vegetables.  My family liked it both ways.  I did not use frozen chicken -- I used defrosted, and cooked for 3 hours on high.  It was fall apart after just the three hours.
The recipe did not make enough sauce for us, so the second time I increased the sauce.  The taste and ease of this recipe are why I am giving it 5 stars.

None
country:
None
text:
We all loved this. After reading other reviews and considering our preferences, I made the following alterations - added one chopped onion, 3 cloves of garlic (minced) and 1/2 cup chicken broth. I put it in the crock pot before I left for work in the morning, came home and shredded the chicken, added about 1/4 cup flour mixed with a little water to prevent lumps, and cooked it for about 1/2 hour more. We ate it with baked potatoes and my husband took leftovers and made a sandwich out of it the next day. Quick, easy, tasty, enjoyed by even the picky "I don't like chicken" eater in the family. And the ingredients are all something I have on hand. Great recipe.
