text:
Yum!  Like others, I cooked the chicken in the slow cooker with 1 can chicken broth 4 hours on high, then drained and shredded.  The sauce wasn't too runny - just perfect!  The combo of ingredients is a bit strange, but it tasted great on a toasted hoagie, and the leftover to make a bbq chicken pizza (great way to "hide" leftovers.)  If you use a BBQ sauce you like, then you'll love this recipe.  We used Gertie's bbq sauce (comes in a jar) - delicious!

I have never eaten so many BBQ chicken sandwiches in one sitting.  This was the best thing I've made in my slow cooker so far.  I used Cattlemen's Kansas City BBQ and store brand Italian dressing.  I still thought it tasted incredible, but I imagine with higher qualities it would be even better.  I don't like putting frozen chicken in the crock pot, so I put mine in thawed on low for three and a half hours, then I shredded it and cooked it on low another hour.  Will absolutely make again.

text:
I was surprised by how amazing this chicken was! It tasted better than my favorite bbq place, which is saying a lot since I'm from the south! I used 3/4 bottle of Sweet Baby Ray's for 3 large chicken breasts. I also added peppers and some onion. It looked like a lot of sauce until I shredded the chicken and then it was perfectly proportionate. SOO GOOD!

text:
I had a rough start with my crock pot (open lid then off outlet) and this still came out amazingly. I picked this recipe one day because I could just throw in chicken breasts straight from my freezer. Of course after my initial mishaps I had to defrost said chicken to make it on time. In the end I cooked it on High for 2 hours, then pulled the chicken and cooked it on Low for another Hour. The only change I made to the sauce was adding a diced onion. It was delicious on toasted hamburger buns with garlic salt. We were so excited to have so many leftovers. We will definitely make this again. So much gain for so little effort!

I can't believe how good this was...we love our BBQ sauce and are quite picky so I didn't know how well it would go over considering the Italian dressing.  The first time I didn't follow the cooking instructions because I had actually made two chicken breasts in the crockpot for soup and changed my mind so I shredded it and halved the sauce recipe and put all back in the crockpot to heat on low for an hour...turned out great.  The second time I made it as directed and didn't like it as well, the sauce was thinner and I couldn't trim & shred the chicken as easily.  I'll be using this recipe again & again.

text:
Wow, I don't know if I did something wrong with this one, but it was a BIG disappointment.  Roundly disliked by all family members.  It was very strong tasting.  It would probably be better with a different BBQ sauce.  I used a zesty sauce, and would opt for something milder if anyone around here would allow me to make it again. I put this in the crock pot before leaving for a full day, and it cooked closer to 9 hours, so was probably overcooked as well.  My suggestions are cook it closer to 6 hours than 8, and use a mild sauce.

text:
Excellent and easy.  I used fresh chicken breasts, Baby Ray's Honey BBQ Sauce and fat-free Italian dressing.  Because I had no brown sugar, I just used some white sugar and honey.  Not having any Worcestershire sauce, I shrugged and just sprinkled in some dry minced onion.  Even with all my substitutions, it came out delicious, tender and was easy to shred right in the crock.  To keep it gluten-free, I served it with tortilla chips instead of rolls.  Delicious!

text:
I have to start off by saying that I didn't cook my frozen chicken breast in the sauce because I didn't want it to be watered down like some of the reviewers stated. I cooked the frozen chicken breast in some water seasoned with chicken bouillon granules once the chicken was mostly cooked I drained the water and added the bbq sauce ~ i used sweet baby rays ~ and the zesty italian salad dressing. There was no need to shred the meat it was so tender it came apart while stirring in the sauce. Cooked for a couple more hours in the sauce and these were perfect!!!!!!! I cooked on low the entire time.

In a 6 quart cooker, I used 4 large chicken breasts, did NOT use brown sugar.  Added jalapenos, some cayenne pepper and a sliced onion (about 4 hours in).  Shredded at 6 hours, and ate at around 8 hours (on low setting).  Put it on a ciabatta roll. DELICIOUS!

I also used fresh chicken and shredded after cooking for 4 hours on low and continued to cook for 1 more hour.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2299219.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was skeptical.  Our favorite bbq sauce is Jack Daniels Original No. 7, which is a strong sauce, and I wasn't sure that chicken saturated in that sauce would be edible.  I was wrong.  I used Kraft Zesty Italian dressing, and added a whole diced onion and minced garlic.  The sugar also mellowed the flavor of the sauce.  As other reviewers mentioned, there appears to be too much sauce before shredding the chicken, but it makes the perfect amount, in my opinion.  I used 6 fresh chicken breasts, and fed six people for dinner.  I also had enough left over for lunch for four.  I served on toasted buns with pasta salad and corn on the cobb.  Everyone loved it!  Also, it's an ideal dish for college students - basic ingredients and simple preparation.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/362072.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh man!! This stuff is great, and OMG it is so easy!! The first time I used the slow cooker on high for the recommended time, did as others did by taking it out about an hour before to shred the chicken. I use only 4 chicken breast instead of 6, and it still makes plenty!! I did not change the quantity of ingredients either, the chicken just soaks it right up. A tip to some though, as it is cooking, it will get very watery!! I was extremely concerned my first time, because the mixture had turned into soup and I thought I had done something wrong.   The second time I made it (within one week of each other) I put the slow cooker on low for about 6 hours, again shredding the chicken to cook for the last hour. This time, the chicken just fell apart! I couldn't even get it out of the pot. It was fabulous as usual, but was a little watery. I suppose next time I cook on low I will reduce the amount liquids to see if it helps.   This is my new favorite!!! Thanks for the great recipe!

5

text:
Love this recipe! I don't know what I liked more the taste or the ease of preparing.  I used fat free Wishbone Italian and Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ and the only change I made was to add about 1T. of minced jarred  garlic.  I used fresh (not frozen) breasts and cooked on low for 4 hrs.  I shredded the chicken after 3 hours and added a bit of flour to thicken.  I served this on hard rolls with cheddar on top.  This will be a definate picnic staple.

5 stars because it is such an easy way to get excellent results.  The flavor of the bbq sauce comes through, so make sure you use one that you like, but the extra ingredients make it different. text:
Great recipe and sooooo easy!!! Made just 1 change. I never cook chicken with out adding onion. LOVE chicken but cannot stand the smell when it cooks, hence the onion. Did not have the problems some other reviewers had with their dish. Used Jack Daniel's Barbecue sauce. Added a little water to bottle to get all of sauce so gravy was a little thin. Served dish as shown with corn on the cob(frozen) and green beans. Excellent meal, family liked it. Made dish for Thursday night dinner, had leftovers last night(Friday) and looking forward to having barbecue sandwiches for lunch today(Saturday). Love pulled pork, never thought about pulled chicken until now. This recipe is a definite keeper!!!

text:
I have made this recipe several times now and it is awesome!  My adjustments include using Kraft zesty italian dressing, Splenda brown sugar blend (1 Tbsp instead of 1/4 cup), and soy sauce when I had no Worcestershire.  Despite previous comments on buying cheap sauce, I did use the 99c Kraft BBQ sauce (honey hickory smoke) and it turned out great.  This makes great sandwiches, paninis and potato topping.  I even mixed it with egg noodles as a leftover the following night and it was good.  :)

I made this for dinner tonight and it was GREAT! I cooked thawed chicken breast in the crock pot for 2 hours on low and 1 1/2 on high. I didn't have italian dressing so I used greek dressing that I had on hand. I also added red onion and garlic. I first cooked the chicken with onion garlic dressing, worcestershire sauce and brown sugar. Once the chicken was cooking I drained some of the liquid out and then added a bottle of sweet baby rays BBQ sauce. We had it on a whole wheat hamber bun,with potatoes and broccli! GREAT DINNER! And SOO easy!

I made this today with Jack Daniels bbq sauce and added white onion, Cayenne Pepper, Apple Cider Vinegar, salt, pepper and the rest of the original ingrediance. I cooked 3  frozen turkey breast on low for 3 hours and they were done! Then I shreded the chicken and put it back on low for another hour. It cooked a lot faster then I planned but I was home to monitor it. Have yet to taste it. It's sitting on warmer until the husband gets home. Sauce tast reat though. I will be serving it on wheat buns.

text:
Just plain awesome!  I made this chicken just as the recipe states, except I used fat- free Italian dressing because its what we had on hand.  (I was concerned that t was going to be a little vinegary, but it wasn't at all.)  I also took the advice of another reviewer and used a better BBQ sauce.  (Famous Dave's Rich and Sassy.)  I cooked this on high for 4 hours or so, took it out, shredded it and returned it to the crockpot for about 45 minutes on low.  We served this over baked potatoes and it was delicious, but it would be equally good on hoagie buns.  As good as it was when I made it that night, my husband and I both agree that it was even better the next day!  5 stars ... We'd give it 6 if we could!

I thought this chicken was wonderful.  Not only was it simple (how many recipes can you throw frozen chicken in a pot?!) but it was so delicious.  We served it over brown rice last night, and tonight we'll have it as sandwiches with french fries and salad.  And for 300 calories, you can't beat that!  Mine made enough for 10 people too, so I'm sure it's less than that.  I'm allergic to an ingredient in almost all salad dressings so I made my own Italian with half oil, half vinegar and some Italian seasoning & garlic powder.  This was great  and I can't wait for the leftovers tonight!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2618091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used six VERY frozen, VERY large chicken breasts for this recipe.  I substituted Ken's low fat Caesar dressing for the Italian because it is what I had on hand.  Everything else I followed exactly.  I took the chicken out after cooking on low for six hours and it was VERY close to being overdone - the reason for four stars.  This was probably perfectly cooked at 5 hours.  Cooking it for 8 hours would have been a disaster.  When I took the chicken out to shred the sauce looked VERY soupy but once I shredded all the breasts and put the chicken back in the crockpot to keep warm until dinner time, it was just the right amount of sauce to coat all the chicken.  I will definitely make this again. It made enough for my family of three hearty eaters to enjoy last night, enough for my husband to take two sandwiches for lunch, and enough to freeze for a future meal.  I did want to mention I used Sweet Baby Ray's barbecue sauce, it's the only BBQ sauce we use.

text:
This recipe was very easy and came out delicious! All my friends loved it.  I made this recipe exactly how it says except I didn't use the Worcestershire sauce only because I didn't have any on hand.  I cooked it on high for 4 hours and then let it sit on low for a few more hours and then just kept it on warm for a few more to let the flavors soak in  and the sauce thicken (I only did this because I had the time to do it).  I also used Jack Daniels Masterpiece bbq sauce as I read it was best to use the more expensive kind.  Half-way during the cooking, I used a fork and shredded the chicken and it makes so much; perfect to have for leftovers.  I highly recommend this recipe. It's SOOO good!!!

text:
This was awesome! It was just as good, if not better than, our local bbq joint. BBQ sauce I used (and only ever use) was Sweet Baby Ray's. I made a few changes to the directions, I boiled my chicken for at least an hour to make it really tender and falls apart easily, while that was boiling, I put all ingredients in crock pot and let simmer while chix was cooking, and after I added chix, just let it cook on high for about 2 hrs and I felt it was long enough, flavors melded good. Next time I would probably just do on stove, I didn't feel it was necessary to do in crockpot, unless I won't be home and wanted to come home to a cooked meal.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy, delicious and healthy too.  I used Stubb's bbq sauce which is only 30 calories per 2 tbs serving.  I used the entire 18 ounce bottle.  I also used light italian dressing.  I omitted the brown sugar but it is so sweet from the bbq sauce that it really doesn't need it.  I only used 2 1/2 pounds of chicken since that is all I had on hand.  I also added a diced sweet onion.  I cooked it for 4 hours on low.  Then I shredded the chicken and cooked it for another 45 minutes on low.  It is juicy and saucey and perfect for sandwhiches.  I will put it over Arnold's thins and over hamburger buns for the kids.

Had it tonight for dinner and it was delish.  My husband ate three!  We love BBQ and this recipie is a keeper.  I will only do one thing differently next time and that is omit the brown sugar. text:
Great!  I added liquid smoke, used honey barbeque sauce, and reduced the brown sugar to half the amount listed because of the sugar/sweetness in the bbq sauce. I also didn't have enough Italian dressing, so I used what little I had along with some Caesar Italian.  I shredded the chicken after one hour on high and about 4 1/2 hours on low, then added it back to the slow cooker and cooked on low for 40 more minutes.

I just made this recipe for the first time and...OMG!!! I made the recipe exactly as stated, but took other reviewer's suggestions and used Sweet Baby Ray's bbq sauce, added half an onion and a little minced garlic. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  It couldn't be more simple.  I needed a meal to feed a crown of out-of-town guests.  I used 6 large fresh chicken breasts (about 3 lbs.) and cooked it on low for 6 hours.  I then shredded the chicken with a fork (it was very tender).  I did not need to thicken this sauce.  All the sauce absorbed into the shredded chicken. I used Sweet Baby Rays Barbeque Sauce (the only one I use) and Kraft Robusto Italian Dressing.  I served it on large rolls.  We had enough for days.  I even froze some of it.  Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had enough time to cook only on high, I think low would have been a bit better.  If you use "Sweet Baby Ray's Barbeque Sauce" you should cut down on the brown sugar! I had to use soy sauce as I did not have the Worchestire  sauce (sp), and I threw in some of the oil and vinegar dressing I had, as I had no Italian per se. Barbeque recipes are very forgiving.  I did shred the chicken, a good idea, and was glad I had put a specialized plastic bag in the crock pot so the sauce did not burn on.  Served over baked potatoes was delicious. With small chicken breasts, only about 4 - 5 ounces each, it makes enough for about 4 people.  This could be doubled in a large slow cooker, I imagine, for a party.

This was absolutely AWESOME! I used Jack Daniels Hickory Honey BBQ sauce. I thought shredding it would be difficult, but I just put a chunk of cooked chicken on a cutting board and used a fork in each hand to pull it apart. I cant wait to try this on hoagie rolls, or hamburger buns. Mmmmm MMMM Awesome!! (and so easy)

text:
Very good, but heres a tip if you are making it ahead of time.  Cook it 7 hours, then when time to heat, you can either cook for 30 minutes in the crockpot or microwave it for a while. (not exactly sure about timing) Also: DOUBLE THE SAUCE RECIPE! this way, reheating it won't make it evaporate.  Good Luck! This is a delicious recipe.  Oh yeah, and a good barbecue sauce is Montgomery inn.  Also, if you like it sweet, add an extra 1/8 cup or so brown sugar.

text:
I defrosted some boneless chicken breasts (thought there were 3 or 4 halves in the pkg but there were only 2) and put them in the slow cooker, reducing the recipe since it calls for 6 halves.  The house filled with an absolutely wonderful aroma.  I used KC Masterpiece Original BBQ sauce and homemade Italian dressing.  After a few hours on high I turned the cooker to low and let them sit until all were home for dinner.  Taking someone else's advice I shredded/chopped up the chicken in the cooker about 30 mins before serving and let it absorb the sauce. Served on bread, it was divine.  The family could not get enough, I wish there were leftovers for today.

It was definitely better the second day.  I defrosted my frozen chicken breasts for about 10 minutes.  I cooked the chicken with one can of chicken broth until I could shred the chicken.  I then drained, shredded, and added the bbq mixture (used sweet baby rays) along with some onion and green pepper.  I did not add brown sugar...the bbq is sweet enough so I thought brown sugar would be over the top.  I would make it again...my dh who loves bbq chicken said it was ok the first day but definitely better the second!

text:
This was SO GOOD!! I used 3 frozen boneless skinless chicken breasts. I cooked them on high for 4 hrs. I was worried they would come out tough, but they were so tender you could cut them with a fork. After 4 hours I took them out and shredded them and then added them back to the sauce and cooked it for a little bit longer. I used the BBQ sauce Big Al's K.C. Bar-B-Q Sauce from this site. I didn't add the brown sugar b/c the bbq sauce was sweet enough. It was awesome! We ate it on bread. I served it with potato salad and baked beans. We have plenty for left overs and I can't wait for lunch tomorrow! This will def. be a regular in our rotation!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight and served it on Kaiser rolls.  It smelled and looked great but was WAY too sweet for us. I thawed the breasts and cooked them in chicken broth on high for 3 hours, drained the broth, shredded the chicken and then put it back in with the rest of the ingredients (plus some onion, bell pepper and garlic).  Very easy.  I will try again without any brown sugar.  We were really disappointed with the sweetness - it smelled so good!

This is still cooking and already it tastes GREAT!!! The only reason I gave it 4 stars and not 5 is because I made some changes...I did as one viewer said and cooked the chicken in 1 cup chicken broth, some garlic powder, and salt and pepper on high for 4 hours. I also added some chopped onion and a little bit of jalepeno juice to give it a kick. I shredded the chicken and drained most of the fat, and then added the bbq sauce/dressing mixture (which sounded so weird) and am cooking it for 2 more hrs. on low. The house smells wonderful! I will be serving this over baked potatoes!

text:
this is a great recipe for company. Although like others, there is no need for the brown sugar. The BBQ sauce has all the sugar you need. Use good BBQ sauce and I add chicken broth (added after the rest of sauce - enough to cover breasts in pot) to make sure there is enough juice. Add back in pot after you shred it. It will look like there is too much juice, until you add shredded chicken back into pot to soak up the flavor and juice. Perfect!

text:
Here's how you can ruin a recipe by try improvising - I used chicken wingettes with skin on and bones in ~ I don't know what I was thinking! Left it on high for over six hours. Used Jack Daniels BBQ sauce & omitted all other ingredients except for some sliced onion and garlic thrown in. I thought maybe the JD would stand on its own. However, using chicken with skin on rendered too much fat. So I had to let it cool on paper towels and hand pulled out the skin and grizzle, the meat fell of the bones and was shredded. It looked like it might be saved but turned out more like chicken soup in barbecue sauce. Tried it over rice but the sauce was just too over powering. Next time I'll follow the recipe verbatim. Really not fair for me to rate this since I made a mess out of something as simply. So giving it 3*'s until my family lets me attempt to give it another go.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I am making this right now for my husband's birthday as a surprise.  I followed some other reviewer's suggestions and slow-cooked my chicken for about 6 hours this morning in broth, drained, shredded, and returned to the crockpot and added the other ingredients.  In the middle of all this, I realized I don't have any Italian dressing, which is something I always have on hand!  In a panic, I came across the "Italian Dressing Mix" recipe on this website and whipped up a batch.  I didn't much care for it, but it's all I had so I added it to the bbq.  I was afraid to even taste it, but it is DELICIOUS!  Unbelievably easy and so wonderful, even with not-so-great dressing!  I know my bbq-lover will be impressed tonight!  Thanks for a great recipe!

Edited to add: ten years and six kids later I still make this delicious BBQ several times a year. I don't always "precook" my chicken either. It never fails to impress. The Italian dressing mix has also become a staple, I was wrong in my initial assessment - an overnight sit is all it needs for those flavors to meld and become a really great dressing. Still one of the hub's favorites and all my hardworking boys gobble this up.

text:
WOW!  What a tasty EASY recipe.  My super picky son loves it!  I follow the recipe exactly (I do add cornstarch to thicken sauce).  My change comes in the end. When I pull out the chicken to shred, I add the cornstarch.  The big change is I add a can of Great Northern Beans when I add the shredded chicken back to the sauce.  I let it cook for anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour (or until I am ready to serve dinner). My other change is that I serve the chicken and beans over rice.  This is a super easy, super delicious meal.

This is one of the best barbeque chicken recipes I have found.  I followed the suggestions of other reviewers and cooked my chicken on high for four hours, then removed it and shredded it.  I stirred in 2 tbs of flour to thicken it and added the shredded chicken back into the crock pot.  I cooked it on low for another hour, and it came out perfect.  Serve with sweet potato fries.

text:
One word YUMMY!!! Next time I may cut down on the brown sugar ONLY because my kids said it was too sweet(I should mention they are extremely picky eaters)My husband and I both ate seconds and then made sandwiches the next day with the leftovers. I used sweet baby rays bbq sauce and good seasons italian dressing made with balsamic vinegar. After cooking on low for about 4 1/2 hours I shredded the chicken and continued to cook for an additional 2 1/2 hours. At that point the sauce was nicely thickened and caramalized. I can't wait to make this again!Thanks for the recipe

I threw in boneless breasts and tenderloins because I didn't have enough chicken breasts.  I did exactly as written but when I came home from work I spooned out the chicken and set aside.  I quickly and easily strained the sauce in the crockpot, added to a saucepan, and brought to a boil.  I mixed about a tablespoon to a tablespoon and a half of cornstarch in a half cup of water.  I whisked it into the boiling bar-b-q "Gravy", and served over the pieces of chicken AND red skin mashed potatoes.  I chose not to shred the chicken, and Let me tell you MAKE THIS TODAY!!!  Thank you for one of the best recipes I have found here!

text:
This is a very easy and delicious recipe. I only made 3 fresh chicken breasts, adjusting the recipe as needed. Famous Dave's Rich and Sassy was my bbq sauce of choice (yummy!) I slow cooked the meal on high for the first half hour and then on low for 2 and a half hours. I took the meat out and shredded it. Then I put it back in the slow cooker for an additional hour on low. Once it was done, I added a little more bbq sauce to the mixture, since a lot of the liquid was soaked up after I shredded the meat. It turned out great! This is a must try!

I love how simple this is to prepare. Bf really liked it; I thought it was okay, but I am not the biggest fan of bbq sauce anyway.  It's definitely something I'll make again bc it is so easy and a great quick meal for weekdays.  Thanks!

text:
This was just ok.  I used my favorite *homemade* BBQ sauce and winced when I added the dressing, sugar, and w. sauce. It watered down and changed the flavor of a perfectly good BBQ sauce! So many of the reviews say "use a good sauce", but let me also add to definitely use a bottled sauce that might need some extra "zest", like the italian dressing, sugar, and w. sauce.  The chicken was moist, it wasn't too runny after I shredded it, and I added more BBQ sauce at the end - it needed it to make up for the watered down tasting sauce it cooked in.  I might make this again in a pinch, with a bottled sauce.

text:
I am a busy mom of 4 sons and admittedly not much of a cook. So, I tried the simplest version possible by trying several tips I read about. This is what I did: cooked chicken breasts in 1/2 cup of chicken broth in my slow cooker (for about 3 hours on high). Then, I shredded the cooked chicken and added Jack Daniels b-b-que sauce to the slow cooker and cooked for another 2 hours. The chicken was moist and tasted great! We put it on potato rolls and ate with rice and a green salad.

Absolutely wonderful! Super easy to put together, tastes delicious! Very tender. I cooked them on low heat for a total of about 7 hours. The only thing I did differently was I added more sauce (bbq/worchestershire/italian dressing) to the crock pot after shredding the breasts and realizing I would need more liquid. (I used Jack Daniel's Original No. 7 recipe.) I let the shredded chicken cook with the sauce a while longer... it was very tender and flavorful! Definite keeper!! I'm certain this would taste just as good with unshredded chicken!

I give this 3 stars because it was so incredibly easy to make. It wasn't a "Wow" meal though. The chicken was dry and I cooked it on low and checked it often during the last couple of hours of cooking to make sure I did not over cook it. The 'sauce' was a little oily and had a weird flavor to it. I used Dave's BBQ sauce and name brand Italian dressing (I use these all the time and love the flavors of both) but the taste just didn't seem to really be that great. This is only something I will cook again if I have nothing else in my house to throw together. It will not be added to my dinner rotation.

text:
I used a mustard based "South Carolina" style bbq sauce because that's my favorite.  I used 18oz. because that was the size of the bottle but followed the rest of the recipe.  I cooked it on low for 4 hours, shredded the chicken and returned it to the sauce, and cooked 2 more hours on low.  I used a little flour to thicken the sauce.  This was delicious with a nice little kick to it.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
I got a crock pot for Xmas and this was the first recipe I tried.  I did as others suggested and added chicken broth (about 3/4 can), and added a little cornstarch to thicken the sauce.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's Original BBQ sauce and it was delicious.  I can't wait to make it again, trying different sauces.  I can see how the BBQ sauce you use can make or break this dish.  Something cheap and too tangy might ruin it.  Next time I will try something a little smokier tasting, and use a TAD less Italian Dressing.  (I used less than the recipe called for and it was still a little too intense for me.)  All in all, this was a GREAT recipe.  My fiance LOVED it, and the two of us managed to finish the whole thing in just 2 days.  I HIGHLY recommend.  Thanks!

My husband and I really liked this recipe.  We only used three frozen chicken breasts and cooked the chicken in broth.  I put garlic powder, salt and pepper on the chicken as stated before in a review.  After 2 1/2 hours on low, they were cooked and ready to shred.  I dumped the liquid and still made the full amount of sauce (we like extra sauce) and combined it with the chicken on low for 1 hour.  It was WONDERFUL.  We used Rudy's barbeque sauce (it's a TX bbq joint that sells it's own sauce...the original was quite spicy, so I'll probably use the Rudy's Sissy sauce next time).

Let me start out by saying that this was very tasty! I threw in 3 large chicken breast, let them cook all day on LOW, and then shredded them and served them in pita pockets. However... text:
Great recipe. I used chicken breast strips (not frozen) and followed the cooking time.  The first time they came out terribly dry and was reluctant to try it again, but the sauce was divine. I didn't shred them the first time because I am not crazy about shredded chicken.  The second time I used fresh chicken breast strips and cooked on low for 4 hrs.  I checked them after 3hrs and they were moist and falling apart. So I shredded them and let them cook for the last hour.  I put them on toasted rolls. Everyone loved them. The came out wonderful!  Now I am a fan of shredded chicken!

I tried this recipe when it was too rainy to barbecue. I followed advice from the other comments and slow-cooked the chicken on high, alone with a can of chicken broth, then drained and shredded it. The chicken was very tender, we served on toasted wheat buns, and it was just as good as barbecue from the grill.

I made this when we had friends over, and everyone loved it! We served them on buns with smoe shredded Mozzarella cheese overtop... even my DH who is such a picky eater has requested i make enough of it so there is left overs to bring to work the next day in his lunch!!

The 2nd time i made it we had fresh chicken breast -- so I cooked it in chicken broth for 2 hours on high. Strained it & forked it apart. Then added the Bullseye BBQ, etc. and let it cook on high for another hour and 15 mins?? Then the hubby couldn't wait anymore and dug in. :D

It was perfect!!! Not dry at all.. and time friendly when coming home and preparing it AFTER work.

country:
None
text:
I am rating this based on ease of prep, inexpensive ingredients used, versatility of finished preparation,and the fact that one can have a hot meal in the summer without heating up a kitchen.  Sauce can be tinkered with to suit one's taste.  I would suggest both a good barbecue sauce and robust italian dressing for a good outcome.  I added 1 can of diced petite cut tomatoes,chopped vidalia, garlic cloves, green pepper, and onion soup mix to 6 bone in skinless breasts.  Made this into minced barbecue and could be served over potatoes or rice, or on a bun.  I added the sauce until it just covered and had some leftover.

text:
Easy and tasty.  Will make again.  I took the advice of others and shredded the chicken towards the end and put it back in the crockpot for an hour.  Drizzled olive oil on hoagie rolls and toasted them up on a grill pan.  Made very good sandwiches.  I'm glad I shredded the chicken because I tasted it while shredding it and thought that it was a bit dry - not awfully dry, but I'm not sure I would've liked it as much whole.  When I was talking to my husband and my mother about the recipe and I said it was chicken, they both said "this is chicken?!" - they thought it was pork.  hehehe  Not bad...the flavor of pork, but made with healthier chicken.
